title: Crash fix
contents:
Index: ChangeLog
===================================================================
--- ChangeLog   (revision 14258)
+++ ChangeLog   (working copy)
@@ -1,5 +1,13 @@
 2006-05-09  Anders Carlsson  <acarlsson@apple.com>
 
+        Reviewed by NOBODY (OOPS!).
+
+        * loader/TextDocument.cpp:
+        (WebCore::TextTokenizer::write):
+        Use the correct variable to prevent crashes.
+
+2006-05-09  Anders Carlsson  <acarlsson@apple.com>
+
         Reviewed by Darin.
 
         http://bugzilla.opendarwin.org/show_bug.cgi?id=8808
Index: loader/TextDocument.cpp
===================================================================
--- loader/TextDocument.cpp     (revision 14258)
+++ loader/TextDocument.cpp     (working copy)
@@ -61,7 +61,7 @@
         rootElement->appendChild(body, ec);
 
         RefPtr<Element> preElement = m_doc->createElementNS(xhtmlNamespaceURI, "pre", ec);
-        body->appendChild(m_preElement, ec);
+        body->appendChild(preElement, ec);
         
         m_preElement = preElement.get();
     }

title: SML/NJ continuation code
contents:
open SMLofNJ.Cont ;
fun m f x =
  let
    fun search n =
      callcc (fn k => (f (fn j => if j < n then x j else throw k (search (n+1))) ; n))
  in
    search 0
  end

title: Take all between the two []
contents:
Say I have this:

# Following line added by [More code cleanup                                                                                                     
# zedek@gnu-rox.org**20060417203615                                                                                                              
                                                                                                                                                 
 * Added copyright header                                                                                                                        
 * Added rcirc-pals                                                                                                                              
 * Removed some more ERC old stuff                                                                                                               
]

How can I get all the part between [].

I ended with that, but it is ugly:

 "^#[ \t]Following line added by[ \t]\\[.+[ \t\n][^\]]+"

title: pivot
contents:
(define (pivot L)
  (let ((first-L-elt (car L)))
    (define (iter L1 L2 L3 acc)
      (cond ((null? acc) (list L1 L2 L3))
	    ((< first-L-elt (car acc)) (iter (cons (car acc) L1) L2 L3 (cdr acc)))
	    ((= first-L-elt (car acc)) (iter L1 (cons (car acc) L2) L3 (cdr acc)))
	    ((> first-L-elt (car acc)) (iter L1 L2 (cons (car acc) L3) (cdr acc)))
	    (else (iter L1 L2 L3 (cdr L)))))
    (iter '() '() '() L)))

title: patch for (most of) text cursor brokenness
contents:
Index: clim-area.lisp
===================================================================
RCS file: /project/mcclim/cvsroot/mcclim/Goatee/clim-area.lisp,v
retrieving revision 1.33
diff -u -r1.33 clim-area.lisp
--- clim-area.lisp      1 Apr 2006 07:58:37 -0000       1.33
+++ clim-area.lisp      9 May 2006 13:22:04 -0000
@@ -219,11 +219,11 @@
   (let ((cursor (cursor record)))
     (multiple-value-bind (x1 y1 x2 y2) (call-next-method)
       (values x1 y1
-              (if cursor
+              (if (and cursor (eq (cursor-visibility cursor) :on))
                   (with-slots (climi::x climi::width) cursor
                      (max x2 (+ climi::x climi::width)))
                   x2)
-              (if cursor
+              (if (and cursor (eq (cursor-visibility cursor) :on))
                   (max y2 (+ y1 (climi::cursor-height cursor)))
                   y2)))))

title: display-func (pró luis)
contents:
(defmacro display-func (callback)
  (let ((sym (gensym)))
    `(progn
      (defcallback ,sym :void ()
	(funcall ,callback))
      (%display-func (callback ,sym)))))

title: possible fix for sb-sprof (LAMBDA ()) problem
contents:
(in-package sb-sprof)

(defun lookup-node (pc)
  (declare (type address pc))
  (or (tree-find pc)
      (let ((info (debug-info pc)))
        (when info
          (let* ((new (make-node info))
                 (key (cons (node-name new)
                            (node-start-pc new)))
                 (found (gethash key *name->node*)))
            (cond (found
                   (setf (node-start-pc found)
                         (min (node-start-pc found) (node-start-pc new)))
                   (setf (node-end-pc found)
                         (max (node-end-pc found) (node-end-pc new)))
                   found)
                  (t
                   (setf (gethash key *name->node*) new)
                   (tree-insert new)
                   new)))))))

title: update check-dom-results
primes
contents:
(define (square x) (* x x))

(define (genlist x y)
  (if (< y 1)
      '()
  (cons x (genlist (+ x 1) (- y 1)))))

(define (findprime x l)
  (if (equal? l '())
      '()
    (if (> (car l) x)
	(car l)
      (findprime x (cdr l)))))

(define (primes x)
  (if (< x 1)
      '()
    (let ((numlist (genlist 1 x)))
      (primes-iter numlist numlist x 2))))

(define (primes-iter plist l x y)
  (if (or (equal? l '()) (> (square y) x))
      l
      (primes-iter plist (chooser l (square y) x y)
                   x (findprime y plist))))

(define (scratch x y l)
  (if (or (equal? '() l) (> x y))
      '()
      (if (equal? (car l) x)
          (cdr l)
          (cons (car l) (scratch x y (cdr l))))))

(define (chooser plist a x y)
  (if (> a x)
      plist
      (chooser (scratch a x plist) (+ a y) x y)))

  `(cond ,(mapcar (lambda (c)
                    `((equal expr ,(car c)) ,(cdr c)))
                    choices)))

(cl-prettyexpand '(case-string "blah"
               ("blah" (+ 1 4))
               ("sploosh" nil)
               (t "no")))

;; expansion:
(cond ((funcall (function (equal expr "blah")) (funcall (function (+ 1 4))))
       (funcall (function (equal expr "sploosh")) (nil))
       (funcall (function (equal expr t)) ("no"))))

title: part of SEXPparser class
contents:
eliminateParentRefs: aTree
	"because the first element of each OrderedCollection is used as a reference to its parent"
	"they must be eliminated before returining the tree"

	aTree removeFirst.
	aTree do: [:item |
		((item className) = 'OrderedCollection')
			ifTrue: [
				self eliminateParentRefs: item.
			].
	].
	^aTree.

parse: aBytestring
	"This is not written in fully Smalltalk style yet"
	| tree currTree switchA verbtaimBytestringLength insideVerbtaimBytestring currBS temp |
	tree := OrderedCollection new.
	tree add: false.
	currTree := tree.
	currBS := ByteString new.
	switchA := Dictionary new.
	switchA at: ${ put: [
		"check if bytestring ends with a }"
		((aBytestring at: (aBytestring size)) = $})
			ifFalse: [ self error: 'SEXPR base64 encoding does not end with a }'. ].
		"decode the bytestring from its base64 representation"
		^self parse: (Base64MimeConverter mimeDecodeToBytes: aBytestring readStream) contents.
	].
	switchA at: $( put: [
		temp := OrderedCollection new.
		currTree add: temp.
		temp add: currTree.
		currTree := temp.
	].
	switchA at: $) put: [
		currTree := currTree at: 1.
	].
	verbtaimBytestringLength := 0.
	switchA at: $0 put: [
		(verbtaimBytestringLength > 0)
			ifTrue: [ verbtaimBytestringLength := verbtaimBytestringLength * 10. ]
			ifFalse: [ self error: 'length field of a verbtaim bytestring starts with a 0'. ].
	].
	switchA at: $1 put: [ verbtaimBytestringLength := (verbtaimBytestringLength * 10) + 1. ].
	switchA at: $2 put: [ verbtaimBytestringLength := (verbtaimBytestringLength * 10) + 2. ].
	switchA at: $3 put: [ verbtaimBytestringLength := (verbtaimBytestringLength * 10) + 3. ].
	switchA at: $4 put: [ verbtaimBytestringLength := (verbtaimBytestringLength * 10) + 4. ].
	switchA at: $5 put: [ verbtaimBytestringLength := (verbtaimBytestringLength * 10) + 5. ].
	switchA at: $6 put: [ verbtaimBytestringLength := (verbtaimBytestringLength * 10) + 6. ].
	switchA at: $7 put: [ verbtaimBytestringLength := (verbtaimBytestringLength * 10) + 7. ].
	switchA at: $8 put: [ verbtaimBytestringLength := (verbtaimBytestringLength * 10) + 8. ].
	switchA at: $9 put: [ verbtaimBytestringLength := (verbtaimBytestringLength * 10) + 9. ].
	switchA at: $: put: [ insideVerbtaimBytestring := true. ].
	insideVerbtaimBytestring := false.
	1 to: (aBytestring size) do: [ :index |
		insideVerbtaimBytestring
			 ifFalse: [
				(switchA at: (aBytestring at: index)) value.
			]
			ifTrue: [
				currBS := currBS , (aBytestring at: index).
				verbtaimBytestringLength := verbtaimBytestringLength - 1.
				(verbtaimBytestringLength = 0)
					ifTrue: [
						insideVerbtaimBytestring := false.
						currTree add: currBS.
						currBS := ByteString new.
					].
			].
	].
     "(currTree ~~ tree)
		ifTrue: [ self error: 'missing a closing brace ) some where in the inputed SEXP'. ]."
	"tree add: aBytestring."
	^(self eliminateParentRefs: tree).

title: real-time two-user editing
contents:
(defmacro receive (vars form &rest body)
  `(multiple-value-bind ,vars ,form ,@body))
(defmacro define (name+parameters &rest body)
  `(defun ,(car name+parameters) ,(cdr name+parameters) ,@body))
(defvar else t)
(fset 'string-length 'length)
(fset 'pair? 'consp)

(defstruct (insertion (:predicate insertion?)
                      (:constructor make-insertion (index text)))
  index
  text)

(defstruct (deletion (:predicate deletion?)
                     (:constructor make-deletion (index length)))
  index
  length)

(defun noop? (x) (eq x 'noop))
(defun make-noop () 'noop)

(define (operation-index op)
  (cond
   ((insertion? op)
    (insertion-index op))
   ((deletion? op)
    (deletion-index op))))

(define (operation-text op)
  (insertion-text op))

(define (operation-length op)
  (cond
   ((insertion? op)
    (string-length (operation-text op)))
   ((deletion? op)
    (deletion-length op))))

(define (operation-end op)
  (+ (operation-index op) (operation-length op)))

(define (it a b)
  (cond
   ((or (noop? a) (noop? b))
    a)
   ((and (insertion? a) (insertion? b))
    (it-ii a b))
   ((and (insertion? a) (deletion? b))
    (it-id a b))
   ((and (deletion? a) (insertion? b))
    (it-di a b))
   ((and (deletion? a) (deletion? b))
    (it-dd a b))
   ((pair? a)
    (cons (it (car a) b) (it (cdr a) b)))
   ((pair? b)
    (it (it a (cdr b)) (car b)))
   (else
    (cdr 'fuck))))

;; FIXME: Special case when (= (index a) (index b))
(define (it-ii a b)
  (if (<= (operation-index a) (operation-index b))
      a
      (make-insertion (+ (operation-index a) (operation-length b))
                      (operation-text a))))

(define (it-id a b)
  (cond
   ((<= (operation-index a) (operation-index b))
    a)
   ((>= (operation-index a) (operation-end b))
    (make-insertion (- (operation-index a)
                       (operation-length b))
                    (operation-text a)))
   (else                                ; A starts inside B
    (make-insertion (operation-index b) (operation-text a)))))

(define (it-di a b)
  (cond
   ((< (operation-end a) (operation-index b))
    a)
   ((< (operation-index a) (operation-index b))
    (let ((distance (- (operation-index b) (operation-index a))))
      (cons (make-deletion (operation-index a) distance)
            (make-deletion (operation-end b)
                           (- (operation-length a) distance)))))
   (else                                ; B in range of A
    (make-deletion (+ (operation-index a) (operation-length b))
                   (operation-length a)))))

(define (it-dd a b)
  (cond
   ((< (operation-end a)
       (operation-index b))
    a)
   ((>= (operation-index a) (operation-end b))
    (make-deletion (- (operation-index a) (operation-length b))
                   (operation-length a)))
   ((and (<= (operation-index b) (operation-index a))
         (>= (operation-end b) (operation-end a)))
    (make-noop))
   ((and (<= (operation-index b) (operation-index a))
         (< (operation-end b) (operation-end a)))
    (make-deletion (operation-index a)
                   (operation-length b)))
   ((and (> (operation-index b) (operation-index a))
         (>= (operation-end b) (operation-end a)))
    (make-deletion (operation-index a)
                   (- (operation-index b) (operation-index a))))
   (else                                ; B fully inside A
    (make-deletion (operation-index a)
                   (+ (- (operation-index b)
                         (operation-index a))
                      (- (operation-end a)
                         (operation-end b)))))))

(define (apply-operation op str)
  (cond
   ((noop? op)
    str)
   ((deletion? op)
    (string-append
     (substring str 0 (operation-index op))
     (substring str (operation-end op))))
   ((insertion? op)
    (string-append
     (substring str 0 (operation-index op))
     (operation-text op)
     (substring str (operation-index op))))
   ((pair? op)
    (apply-operation (cdr op) (apply-operation (car op) str)))))

(define (apply-operation-to-buffer op buf &optional proc)
  (save-excursion
    (set-buffer buf)
    (cond
     ((deletion? op)
      (delete-region (operation-index op) (operation-end op)))
     ((insertion? op)
      (goto-char (operation-index op))
      (let ((there (point)))
        (insert (operation-text op))
        (and proc
             (funcall proc there (point)))))
     ((pair? op)
      (apply-operation-to-buffer (car op) buf)
      (apply-operation-to-buffer (cdr op) buf)))))

(define (transform c s)
  (values (it c s) (it s c)))

;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

(defun generate-operation (op)
  (let ((message (make-message op lark-state)))
    (send-message message)
    (push message lark-outgoing)
    (setq lark-state (make-state (1+ (state-mine lark-state))
                                 (state-theirs lark-state)))))

(defstruct (message (:constructor make-message (operation state)))
  operation
  state)

(defstruct (state (:constructor make-state (mine theirs)))
  mine
  theirs)

(defun receive-message (message)
  (setq lark-outgoing
        (mapcan
         (lambda (m)
           (if (< (state-mine (message-state m))
                  (state-theirs (message-state message)))
               nil
             (list m)))
         lark-outgoing))
  (setq lark-outgoing
        (mapcar
         (lambda (m)
           (receive (new-message-op new-m-op)
                    (transform (message-operation message)
                               (message-operation m))
             (setf (message-operation message) new-message-op)
             (make-message new-m-op (message-state m))))
         lark-outgoing))
  (let ((inhibit-modification-hooks t))
    (apply-operation-to-buffer
     (message-operation message) lark-buffer
     (lambda (beg end)
       (add-text-properties
        beg end
        `(face ,(if lark-server-p 'hi-blue 'hi-pink)
          rear-nonsticky t
          front-sticky nil)))))
  (setq lark-state (make-state (state-mine lark-state)
                               (1+ (state-theirs lark-state)))))

(defun lark-before-change-function (beg end)
  (when (/= beg end)
    (generate-operation (make-deletion beg (- end beg)))))

(defun lark-after-change-function (beg end original-length)
  (when (/= beg end)
    (generate-operation
     (make-insertion beg
                     (buffer-substring-no-properties beg end)))))

(defun lark-mode ()
  (add-hook 'before-change-functions 'lark-before-change-function nil t)
  (add-hook 'after-change-functions 'lark-after-change-function nil t)
  (set (make-local-variable 'lark-outgoing) (list))
  (set (make-local-variable 'lark-state) (make-state 0 0))
  (set (make-local-variable 'lark-buffer) (current-buffer)))

(defun lark-server-log (server connection message)
  (save-excursion
    (set-buffer (process-buffer server))
    (process-put connection 'buffer (current-buffer))
    (set-buffer lark-buffer)
    (set (make-local-variable 'lark-network-process) connection)))

(defun lark-start-server (host port)
  (interactive "sHost: \nnPort: ")
  (let ((bn (generate-new-buffer-name "lark-server")))
    (make-network-process :name "lark-server"
                          :buffer bn
                          :host host
                          :service port
                          :coding 'utf-8
                          :filter 'lark-filter
                          :log 'lark-server-log
                          :server t)
    (let ((lb (current-buffer)))
      (save-excursion
        (set-buffer bn)
        (set (make-local-variable 'lark-buffer) lb)))
    (set (make-local-variable 'lark-server-p) t)
    (lark-mode)))

(defun lark-connect (host port)
  (interactive "sHost: \nnPort: ")
  (let* ((bn (generate-new-buffer-name "lark-client"))
         (client-process (make-network-process :name "lark-client"
                                               :buffer bn
                                               :host host
                                               :service port
                                               :coding 'utf-8
                                               :filter 'lark-filter)))
    (let ((lb (current-buffer)))
      (save-excursion
        (set-buffer bn)
        (set (make-local-variable 'lark-buffer) lb)))
    (set (make-local-variable 'lark-network-process) client-process)
    (set (make-local-variable 'lark-server-p) nil)
    (lark-mode)))

(defun message->string (msg)
  (prin1-to-string
   (list
    (let ((op (message-operation msg)))
      (cond
       ((insertion? op)
        (list 'insertion (insertion-index op) (insertion-text op)))
       ((deletion? op)
        (list 'deletion (deletion-index op) (deletion-length op)))
       ((noop? op)
        (list 'noop))))
    (let ((state (message-state msg)))
      (list (state-theirs state) (state-mine state))))))

(defun send-message (msg)
  (when lark-network-process
    (process-send-string lark-network-process (message->string msg))))

(defun maybe-read (buffer)
  (with-current-buffer buffer
    (let ((pos (point)))
      (condition-case err (read (current-buffer))
        (end-of-file (progn (goto-char pos) nil))))))

(defun lark-filter (proc string)
  (with-current-buffer (or (process-buffer proc)
                           (process-get proc 'buffer))
    (save-excursion
      (goto-char (point-max))
      (insert string))
    (let ((message-form (maybe-read (current-buffer))))
      (while message-form
        (destructuring-bind (operation-form (state-mine state-theirs))
            message-form
          (with-current-buffer lark-buffer
            (receive-message
             (make-message 
              (ecase (car operation-form)
                ((insertion) (make-insertion (cadr operation-form)
                                             (caddr operation-form)))
                ((deletion) (make-deletion (cadr operation-form)
                                           (caddr operation-form)))
                ((noop) (make-noop)))
              (make-state state-mine state-theirs)))))
        (setq message-form (maybe-read (current-buffer)))))))

title: Tolerance
contents:
Helen Nuss refers to Canada and the United States basing their culture on Christian principles. She sees only positives from this, "with the result that millions have wanted to emigrate to and enjoy the benefits of our freedom and prosperity." But what is this freedom and prosperity she speaks of? Our freedom to murder natives and steal their land, our freedom to base our economy on the exploitation of slaves from Africa and elsewhere. 
    It is not a matter of freedom, but freedom to whom. She states that a great philosopher said "tolerance is the last virtue of a degenerate society." That 'great' philosopher is James Kennedy, the televangelist who condoned the invasion of Iraq by signing the Land Letter sent to Bush.
    Tolerance is in the middle of overtolerance and narrow mindedness. Not everybody will agree where that middle should be. The narrow mind will not accept anything different. Boasting about christian principles does little justice to the millions of people who have died in the name of One, who would surely not approve. 
    If Jesus died on the cross for your sins, don't injur him further by failing in him, whose message of love and tolerance is an example so regularily skewed.

title: Parsing numbers for fun and profit
contents:
parseNumber :: Parser LispVal
parseNumber = do
  ([e],[r]) <- option ([Nothing],[readDec]) prefix
  let read = runRead r
  s <- many1 $ digit <|> (oneOf $ ['a'..'f']++['A'..'F'])
  i <- read s
  return $ Number (Int i) (fromMaybe Inexact e) -- This isn't quite right, need to analyse the number for its natural exact as well 
  where
    prefix = do
      xs <- many1 preField
      let (es,rs) = unzipWith id xs
      if any (>1) [length es, length rs] then fail "Malformed prefix on number!"
         else return (take 1 $ es ++ [Nothing], take 1 $ rs ++ [readDec])
    preField = try $ do
      char '#'
      x <- oneOf "bodiex"
      return $ case toLower x of
        'b' -> Right readBin
        'o' -> Right readOct
        'd' -> Right readDec
        'x' -> Right readHex
        'e' -> Left $ Just Exact
        'i' -> Left $ Just Inexact
    sign = oneOf "+-"
    readBin = readInt 2 (`elem` "01") digitToInt
    runRead :: ReadS Integer-> String -> Parser Integer
    runRead f s = case [x | (x,t) <- f s, ("","") <- lex t] of
                    [x] -> return x
                    [] -> fail $ "Can't parse number <"++s++">"

title: walk-list
contents:
(defun member-and-position (item list &optional compare)
  (let ((pos -1)
        result
        (compare (or compare #'equal)))
    (while (and list (not result))
      (let ((elt (car list))
            (rest (cdr list)))
        (setq pos (+ pos 1))
        (if (apply compare (list elt item))
            (setq result (cons list pos))
          (setq list rest))))
    result))

	  sfile <- getLine
	  source <- readFile sfile
	  let definitions = selectDef source

	  let guards = selectGuard source
	  let parsedGuards = parseGuard guards
	  putStrLn "Enter target file name:"
	  tfile <- getLine
	  writeFile tfile ( (show parsedDefinitions) ++" " ++ (show parsedGuards))

title: Integer overflow detection
contents:
32bit signed integer overflow/underflow checking
------------------------------------------------

sign bits     add            sub

a -
b -           c -  ov +      c +-

a +
b +           c +  ov -      c +-

a -
b +           c +-           c -  ov +

a +
b -           c +-           c +  ov -

------------------------------------------------
Solution (for c = a + b):

if ((c ^ a) & (c ^ b) >> 31)
        /* overflow / underflow */
else
        /* in range */

Solution (for c = a - b):

if ((a ^ b) & (a ^ c) >> 31)
        /* overflow / underflow */
else
        /* in range */

title: Russel's paradox, lambda calculus and Y (oh my!)
contents:
; Russel's paradox considers the set:
; A = { x : x \notin x }
;  x \in A  \iff  x \notin x
;  A \in A  \iff  A \notin A
;
; .. note \iff is usually spelled \Leftrightarrow or <=>
;
; Transforming this into LC we use the correspondences:
;   set            function
;   element        argument
;   membership     application
;   set formation  lambda abstraction
;   set equality   term equality

; negation can be expressed as the term N where N is never the identity
; .. of course this can't directly be described in LC, but we can use it
; to derive proofs.


; so Russel's set A becomes:

(define A (lambda (x) (N (x x))))

; so let's evaluate:
(A A) => (N (A A))    ; via beta-reduction

; look familiar? Yep, it's a fixed-point. ie:
(Y N) => (N (Y N))

; what does this mean?
;  it's a true assertion according to the premises [A, Y]
;  but if it's true, then N must be the identity!
; hence, we can deduce that there is no term N that is never the identity!
;  ... I find this nearly as mind-blowing as Y itself.

; (adapted from: Classical Recursion Theory, P. Odifreddi, North Holland Press)
;  (part of the "Studies in Logic" series that also includes Barendregt's
;   "The Lambda Calculus: Its Syntax and Semantics")

title: network
contents:
--server.hs
import Network
import Control.Concurrent
import System.IO
import System

forever act = let loop = act >> loop in loop

main = do
  [port] <- getArgs
  s <- listenOn (PortNumber (fromIntegral (read port)))
  forever $ accept s >>= forkIO . worker

worker (handle, hostname, port_number) =
  hGetLine handle >>= hPutStrLn handle >> hFlush handle >> hClose handles

--client.hs
import Network
import Control.Concurrent
import Control.Concurrent.STM
import Control.Monad
import Data.IORef
import System.IO
import System
import System.Time

forever act = let loop = act >> loop in loop

main = do
  (num:ports) <- getArgs
  counts <- fmap concat $ mapM (\port -> sequence (replicate (read num) (worker port)))
    (map (fromIntegral . read) ports)
  track counts 0

track counts lastCount = do
  threadDelay 1000000
  count <- fmap sum $ mapM readIORef counts
  putStrLn $ show (count-lastCount)++" "++show count
  track counts count

worker port = do
  var <- newIORef 0
  forkIO $ forever (do
    h <- connectTo "127.0.0.1" (PortNumber port)
    hSetBuffering h LineBuffering
    hPutStrLn h "Ping"
    "Ping" <- hGetLine h
    hClose h
    v <- readIORef var
    writeIORef var $! v+1)
  return var

title: (member-position)
contents:
(defun member-position (lst value)
  (let ((pos -1)
        result)
    (while (and lst (not result))
      (setq pos (+ pos 1))
      (let ((elt (car lst))
            (rest (cdr lst)))
        (if (equal elt value)
            (setq result pos))
        (setq lst rest)))
    result))

serialization trick - totally crazy?
contents:
;; in response to http://groups.google.com/group/comp.lang.lisp/tree/browse_frm/thread/94a7939a291e40ec/279fa57bdbcdb638?rnum=1&_done=%2Fgroup%2Fcomp.lang.lisp%2Fbrowse_frm%2Fthread%2F94a7939a291e40ec%2F279fa57bdbcdb638%3F#doc_279fa57bdbcdb638

;; we can assume that everything in THING is a simple Lisp type, easily READ or PRINT'd

(defun serialize (thing file function-name &optional (compilep t))
  (with-open-file (s file :direction :output :if-exists :supersede
		     :if-does-not-exist :create)
    (write `(defun ,function-name ()
	      (quote ,thing))
	   :stream s :length nil :level nil :readably t))
  (if compilep
      (compile-file file)
      file))

CL-USER> (progn
	   (defvar thing
	     (loop for x from 1 to 10000
	        collect (loop for y from 1 to 100
		           collect (elt '(a b c d e) (random 5)))))

title: captcha
contents:
;; Palabra base
(define *base-codes* (list->vector (map char->integer
					(string->list "desaweb"))))

;; Fórmula general, num es el valor, start el inicio y el valor de retorno
;; es el código ascii correspondiente
(define (captcha-code->ascii-code num start)
  (- (+ num start) (arithmetic-shift (bitwise-and num start) 1)))

;; La inversa de la anterior
(define (ascii-code->captcha-code ascii start)
  (let loop ([num 0])
    (if (= ascii (captcha-code->ascii-code num start))
      num
      (loop (+ num 1)))))
 
;; Hace una lista que contiene los códigos de inicio, de longitud n.
;; Es una función de utilidad para usar con map en las funciones que siguen.
(define (make-codes-list n)
  (let loop ([i 0] [res '()])
    (if (= i n)
      res
      (loop (+ i 1)
	    (cons (vector-ref *base-codes* (remainder i 7)) res)))))

;; Obtiene la lista de códigos para una cadena.
(define (string->captcha-codes str)
  (reverse
   (map ascii-code->captcha-code 
	(reverse (map char->integer (string->list str)))
	(make-codes-list (string-length str)))))

;; Obtiene una cadena a partir de una lista de códigos.
(define (captcha-codes->string codes)
  (list->string
   (reverse
    (map integer->char
	 (map captcha-code->ascii-code
	      (reverse codes)
	      (make-codes-list (length codes)))))))

;; A partir de la lista de codes generar la cadena para el GET.
(define (captcha-codes->captcha-GET codes)
  (define (num->str n)
    (let ([str (number->string n)])
      (string-append (make-string (- 3 (string-length str)) #\0) str)))
  (apply string-append (map num->str codes)))

;; A partir de la cadena del GET generar la cadena en ascii.
(define (captcha-GET->captcha-codes getstr)
  (let ([len (string-length getstr)])
    (let loop ([i 0] [codes '()])
      (if (>= i len)
	(reverse codes)
	(loop (+ i 3) (cons (string->number (substring getstr i (+ i 3)))
			    codes))))))

title: Shlibs issue in Gnucash
contents:
I am packagin gnucash-1.9.5 It compiles fine, but there is a problem with shared libs:

% gnucash
ERROR: In procedure dynamic-link:
ERROR: file: "libgw-core-utils", message: "dlopen(libgw-core-utils.so, 9): image not found"

There are two splitoffs: gnucash-dev and gnucash-shlibs. When
gnucash-dev is installed, gnucash works fine. gnucash-dev contains the
following file:

% dpkg -c /sw/fink/debs/gnucash-dev_1.9.5-1_darwin-powerpc.deb | grep libgw-core-utils
-rwxr-xr-x root/admin     1502 2006-05-06 19:37:09 ./sw/lib/libgw-core-utils.la
lrwxr-xr-x root/admin        0 2006-05-06 19:37:09 ./sw/lib/libgw-core-utils.dylib -> libgw-core-utils.0.0.0.dylib

while gnucash-libs contains:

% dpkg -c /sw/fink/debs/gnucash-shlibs_1.9.5-1_darwin-powerpc.deb | grep libgw-core-utils
-rwxr-xr-x root/admin    17932 2006-05-06 19:37:09 ./sw/lib/libgw-core-utils.0.0.0.dylib
lrwxr-xr-x root/admin        0 2006-05-06 19:37:09 ./sw/lib/libgw-core-utils.0.dylib -> libgw-core-utils.0.0.0.dylib

It looks like that gnucash needs /sw/lib/libgw-core-utils.dylib
symlink for some reason.

title: Lispy C++ templates
contents:
(defun expt (x)
  (cond ((= 0 x) (out struct result ()
                      "template <typename T>"
                      "static inline T expt(T y) { return 1; }"))
        ((= 1 x) (out struct result ()
                      "template <typename T>"
                      "static inline T expt(T y) { return y; }"))
        (T       (out struct result ()
                      "template <typename T>"
                      "static inline T expt(T y)"
                      "{"
                      "    return #{ (expt (/ x 2)) }::expt(y) *"
                      "           #{ (expt (/ (+ 1 x) 2)) }::expt(y);"
                      "}"))))

title: aufgabe 61
contents:
import List

data BinTree a = BinTree a (BinTree a) (BinTree a) | Empty

treeIso :: (a -> z -> z -> z) -> z -> BinTree a -> z
treeIso comb z0 = iso
    where iso Empty = z0
          iso (BinTree a t1 t2) = comb a (iso t1) (iso t2)

wert :: Num a => BinTree a -> a
wert = treeIso (\a z1 z2 -> a + z1 + z2) 0

maxTeilBaum :: Real a => BinTree a -> BinTree a
maxTeilBaum t = maximumBy cmp (alle_teile t)
    where cmp :: Real a => BinTree a -> BinTree a -> Ordering
          cmp a b = compare (wert a) (wert b)

alle_teile :: BinTree a -> [BinTree a]
alle_teile = treeIso b [Empty]
    where build_tree a (t1, t2) = BinTree a t1 t2
          b a t1s t2s = map (build_tree a) (zip t1s t2s)

maxPfadWert :: Real a => BinTree a -> a
maxPfadWert = treeIso m 0
    where m a w1 w2 = a + max w1 w2

main :: IO ()
main = putStr "Compiles!\n"

title: hGetCont
contents:
-- gets the Contents' without making it impossible to get more
hGetCont hdl = do
   bool <- hWaitForInput hdl 100
   if bool
      then do char  <- hGetChar hdl -- get a character
              char' <- hGetCont hdl -- get the rest of the characters
              return $ char : char'
      else return []

(defcstruct keyboard-symbol
  (scancode :unsigned-char) (sym :uint) (mod :uint) (unicode :unsigned-short))

(defmacro defcevent (name &rest body)
  `(defcstruct ,name (type :unsigned-char) ,@body))

(defmacro defievent (name &rest body)
  `(defcevent ,name (which :unsigned-char) ,@body))

(defcevent active-event (gain :unsigned-char) (state :unsigned-char))
(defievent keyboard-event (state :unsigned-char) (keysym keyboard-symbol))
(defievent mouse-motion-event (state :unsigned-char)
           (x :unsigned-short) (y :unsigned-short) (xrel :short) (yrel :short))
(defievent mouse-button-event (button :unsigned-char) (state :unsigned-char) 
           (x :unsigned-short) (y :unsigned-short))
(defievent joystick-axis-event (axis :unsigned-char) (value :short))
(defievent joystick-ball-event (ball :unsigned-char)
           (xrel :short) (yrel :short))
(defievent joystick-hat-event (hat :unsigned-char) (state :unsigned-char))
(defievent joystick-button-event (button :unsigned-char) (state :unsigned-char))
(defcevent resize-event (w :int) (h :int))
(defcevent expose-event) (defcevent quit-event)
(defcevent user-event (code :int) (data1 :pointer) (data2 :pointer))

(defcunion event
  (type :unsigned-char) (active active-event) (key keyboard-event)
  (motion mouse-motion-event) (button mouse-button-event)
  (jaxis joystick-axis-event) (jball joystick-ball-event)
  (jhat joystick-hat-event)   (jbutton joystick-button-event)
  (resize resize-event) (expose expose-event) (quit quit-event)
  (user user-event))

title: spreadsheet.lisp
contents:
(defpackage :spreadsheet (:use :common-lisp))
(in-package :spreadsheet)

(defvar *allowed-funcs*
  '(+ - * / sin cos tan)
  "Spreadsheet cells can only call these functions.")

(defclass spreadsheet ()
  ((variables :accessor variables :initarg :variables :initform nil)
   (cells :accessor cells :initarg :cells :initform (make-hash-table))))

(defun make-spreadsheet (vars)
  "Create a new spreadsheet with the given variables.  VARS is a
list of (name . initial-value) pairs."
  (make-instance 'spreadsheet :variables vars))

(defmethod cell ((sheet spreadsheet) index)
  (gethash index (cells sheet)))

(defmethod sheet-eval ((sheet spreadsheet) sexp)
  "Evaluate SEXP in SHEET.  Looks up symbols in the variables
list and in the cells themselves.  Lists are treated as function
calls.  If the function name is allowed, then the arguments are
recursively SHEET-EVAL'd and the result is then applied to the
function.  If the expression is neither a symbol nor a
list (e.g. a number), its value is returned."
  (cond
    ((consp sexp)
     (if (member (car sexp) *allowed-funcs*)
	 (eval (cons (car sexp)
		     (mapcar (lambda (item)
			       (sheet-eval sheet item))
			     (cdr sexp))))
	 (error "~A is not allowed within the spreadsheet"
		(car sexp))))
    ((symbolp sexp)
     (or (gethash sexp (cells sheet))
	 (cdr (assoc sexp (variables sheet)))
	 (error "~A is not a variable or cell name"
		sexp)))
    (t (eval sexp))))

(defmethod (setf cell) (new-value (sheet spreadsheet) index)
  "Set the cell at INDEX to NEW-VALUE.  Recompute all cells
afterwards."
  (setf (gethash index (cells sheet)) new-value)
  (maphash (lambda (key value)
	     (setf (gethash key (cells sheet))
		   (sheet-eval sheet value)))
	   (cells sheet)))

(let ((sheet (make-spreadsheet '((one . 1) (pi . pi)))))
  (setf (cell sheet 'a) '(- (+ (sin (/ pi 2)) one)))
  (setf (cell sheet 'b) '(* (- a) 10))
  (maphash (lambda (key value)
	     (format t "~A=~A~%" key value))
	   (cells sheet)))

title: Close Parenthesis; problem happens in CLOSE-PAIR-AND-NEWLINE when it cals INDENT-CURRENT-LINE
contents:
(define-command (com-close-parenthesis :name t
                                       :command-table lisp-table)
    ()
  (close-pair-command #\)))

(define-command (com-close-parenthesis-and-newline
                 :name t
                 :command-table lisp-table)
    ()
  (close-pair-and-newline-command #\)))

(defun close-pair-command (close)
  (let ((point (current-point))
        (syntax (current-syntax)))
    (cond ((or (in-string-p point syntax)
               (in-comment-p point syntax))
           (insert-object point close))
          (t (if (in-character-p point syntax)
                 (setf (offset point)
                       (end-offset (expression-at-mark point
                                                       syntax))))
             (move-past-close-and-reindent point syntax)))))

(defun close-pair-and-newline-command (close)
  (close-pair-command close)
  (let ((window (current-window))
        (point (current-point)))
    (insert-object point #\Newline)
    (climacs-gui::indent-current-line window point)
    (if (not (or (end-of-line-p point)
                 (right-bracket-p (object-after point)
                                  (current-syntax))))
        (let ((mark (clone-mark point)))
          (forward-expression mark (current-syntax))
          (indent-region window point mark)))))

(defun move-past-close-and-reindent (mark syntax)
  (up-list mark syntax)
  (let ((mark (clone-mark mark)))
    (backward-object mark)              ;Move to before the close.
    (loop (let ((mark* (clone-mark mark)))
            (climacs-gui::back-to-indentation mark*)
            (cond ((not (mark= mark* mark))
                   (delete-leading-whitespace mark syntax)
                   (return))
                  ((progn
                     (previous-line mark*)
                     (end-of-line mark*)
                     (in-comment-p mark* syntax))
                   (climacs-gui::indent-current-line (current-window)
                                                     mark)
                   (return))
                  (t (climacs-gui::delete-indentation mark)))))))

(defun delete-leading-whitespace (end-mark syntax)
  (let ((mark (clone-mark end-mark)))
    (loop while (and (not (beginning-of-line-p mark))
                     (whitespacep (object-before mark)))
       do (backward-object mark))
    (if (in-character-p mark syntax)
        (forward-object mark))
    (delete-region mark end-mark)))

;;; Randomness that ought to go elsewhere.

(defun current-point ()
  (point (current-window)))

(defun (setf current-point) (new-point)
  (setf (point (current-window)) new-point))

(defun current-buffer ()
  (buffer (current-window)))

(defun current-syntax ()
  (syntax (current-buffer)))

(defun in-character-p (mark syntax)
  (in-type-p mark syntax 'CHARACTER-LEXEME))

require 'osx/cocoa'

class RMUDCommandField <  OSX::NSTextField
  include OSX
  
  def awakeFromNib
    self.setNeedsDisplay(true)
    self.window.setAcceptsMouseMovedEvents(true)
  end

  def isOpaque
    return true
  end
  
  def wantsToHandleMouseEvents
    return true
  end
  
  def acceptsFirstResponder
    return true
  end
  
  def resignFirstResponder
    self.setNeedsDisplay(true)
    return true
  end

  def becomeFirstResponder
    self.setNeedsDisplay(true)
    return true
  end
  
  def keyDown(event)
    puts "BAMF!"
    puts event.inspect
  end
  
  def mouseMoved(event)
    print "."
  end
end

title: remove-file-newline
contents:
(defun remove-file-newline (in-file out-file)
  (let ((next-char (read-char in-file)))
    (when next-char
            (cond ((not (char= next-char #\newline))
                   (write-char next-char out-file)))
            (remove-file-newline in-file out-file))))

title: multi collect
contents:
(defun make-card (value suite)
  `(,value . ,suite))

(defun card-value (card)
  (elt card 0))

(defun card-suite (card)
  (elt card 1))

(defvar *suites* '(heart diamond spade club))
(defvar *face* '(jack king queen ace))

(defun make-deck ()
  (loop for s in *suites* append
	(loop for i from 1 to 10 collecting (make-card i s) for f in *face* collecting (make-card i f)
)))

(define (fish x) (+ x 3))
(define (flap x) (fish x))

  (syntax-rules ()
    ((magic x) (fish x))))
(define-syntax fish
  (syntax-rules ()
    ((fish x) (- x 3))))
(fish 5)   =>  ?

title: mangalore gui
contents:
DRAFT

understanding mangalore gui

The mangalore gui is differnt from the nebula gui as it seems to be a
lightweight,  designer friendly, and to some extent coder free version of a
gui. I'll try to  summarize what I have learned so far by inspecting the gui
code in magalore.

The gui consists of two parts. The first is a file defining the hierarchy
and  called a xui file in event.h. The second part is where 'to some extent'
comes in.  The xui needs an event handler responsible for handling the
events of the loaded  xui file.

The XUI file is not specified by radonlabs but from what I understand it is
not  that difficult to create one by hand. Basically it is a 'normal'
transformnode/gfxnode hierarchy as you would create for your nebual objects.
The  difference is some distinct naming conventions for the nodes and some
custom  attributes. So how would I create a gui for mangalore ? You can use
your prefered  nebula exporter and layout your gui with 3d elements for
example a plane with a  fancy image as a backdrop, some buttons and some
labels. And here managalore gui  elements end. you do not have more than the
three items available. If you would  need more or some different behavior
you would need to create your own classes (for  eventual drag & drop support
for example). Now back to the gui with a plane and  three buttons. Attached
is an example of the described gui without the meshes and  textures, just
the plain XUI (which is nothing else a n2 file). For mangalore the
hierarchy has some additional attributes which can be looked up in the
button/canvas and label code.

All gui items are identified by the custom attribute "rlGui" which only
needs to be  present (you could do it with a bool attribute.

A canvas has a string attribute "rlGuiType" with the value "Canvas" . In the
current implementation only one canvas is active at the time.

A button has a string attribute "rlGuiType" with the value "Button" . A
string  attribute "rlGuiText" with a value for the text on the button (which
does not seem  to be used at all), a string attribute "rlGuiEvent" with a
value specifying which  message event to be sent on pushing the button.
Optionally you can attach four  child shadernodes named
"normal","pressed","mouseover","disabled" which will be  displayed when the
corresponding action is active on the button. 

A label has a string attribute "rlGuiType" with the value "Label" . It does
not  have any other attributes.


The messagehandler is responsible for processing all messages sent by your
gui. On  releasing the left mouse button for example on your menu button
would put the event  you specified for the button to be propagated to your
message handler. The message handler is initially attached to the canvas.
You can write serveral message handlers each responsible for his gui or one
monolithic message handler for your whole game. The message handler will
receive the  messages and should be the responsible instance to route the
messages to the right  places (sending further messages to entities, closing
gui's opening new gui's,  startinggames, stopping them, loading levels,
etc.) The Handling is done in the EventHandler::HandleEvent() function which
is the only part you need to implement. Without it you just have buttons
doing nothing :
-)

title: Ambiguous type variable
contents:
replace (key,value) ((k,v):xs) | key == k = (key,value):xs
                               | otherwise = (k,v): replace (key,value) xs
replace (key,value) [] = [(key,value)]


data (Hashable k) => HashMap k v = HM (Map.IntMap [(k,v)]) deriving (Ord,Eq,Show)

empty = HM Map.empty
singleton k v = insert k v empty

lookup key (HM im) = case Map.lookup (hash key) im of
                       Nothing -> Nothing
                       Just alist -> List.lookup key alist


insert key value (HM im) = case Map.lookup (hash key) im of
                             Nothing -> HM (Map.insert (hash key) [(key,value)] im)
                             Just alist -> HM (Map.insert (hash key) (replace (key,value) alist) im)

title: the function
contents:
static void
diff8x8_s16_u8_mmx (int16_t *dest, uint8_t *src1, int ss1, uint8_t *src2, int ss2)
{
  __asm__ __volatile__ (
#ifdef __APPLE__
    "  .align 4                   \n\t"
#else
    "  .balign 16                   \n\t"
#endif

    "  pxor        %%mm7, %%mm7     \n\t"

    ".rept 8                        \n\t"
    "  movq        (%0), %%mm0      \n\t" /* mm0 = FiltPtr */
    "  movq        (%1), %%mm1      \n\t" /* mm1 = ReconPtr */
    "  movq        %%mm0, %%mm2     \n\t" /* dup to prepare for up conversion */
    "  movq        %%mm1, %%mm3     \n\t" /* dup to prepare for up conversion */
    /* convert from UINT8 to INT16 */
    "  punpcklbw   %%mm7, %%mm0     \n\t" /* mm0 = INT16(FiltPtr) */
    "  punpcklbw   %%mm7, %%mm1     \n\t" /* mm1 = INT16(ReconPtr) */
    "  punpckhbw   %%mm7, %%mm2     \n\t" /* mm2 = INT16(FiltPtr) */
    "  punpckhbw   %%mm7, %%mm3     \n\t" /* mm3 = INT16(ReconPtr) */
    /* start calculation */
    "  psubw       %%mm1, %%mm0     \n\t" /* mm0 = FiltPtr - ReconPtr */
    "  psubw       %%mm3, %%mm2     \n\t" /* mm2 = FiltPtr - ReconPtr */
    "  movq        %%mm0,  (%2)     \n\t" /* write answer out */
    "  movq        %%mm2, 8(%2)     \n\t" /* write answer out */
    /* Increment pointers */
    "  add         $16, %2          \n\t"
    "  add         %3, %0           \n\t"
    "  add         %4, %1           \n\t"
    ".endr                          \n\t"
    "  emms                         \n\t"

     : "+r" (src1),
       "+r" (src2),
       "+r" (dest)
     : "m" (ss1),
       "m" (ss2)
     : "memory"
  );
}

title: possible generic-+ optimization for SBCL/MIPS
contents:
It looks like this is a net win for all code paths. For the non-overflow case you save between 2 and 4 instructions (depending on if you had a negative-signed result or not). For the overflow case you save having to jump around the reboxing of the result. There's a similar optimization for generic--, but I can never remember which way round the xors go. The only question I have is, does it actually work?

--- sbcl-0.9.12-x86-reserve-ebx-2/src/assembly/mips/arith.lisp	2005-08-16 11:20:40.000000000 -0400
+++ sbcl-0.9.12-x86-reserve-ebx-3/src/assembly/mips/arith.lisp	2006-05-06 07:45:28.000000000 -0400
@@ -30,8 +30,8 @@
                           (:temp ocfp any-reg ocfp-offset))
   (inst or temp x y)
   (inst and temp fixnum-tag-mask)
-  (inst beq temp DO-ADD)
-  (inst sra temp1 x n-fixnum-tag-bits)
+  (inst beq temp CHECK-OVERFLOW)
+  (inst addu res x y)
 
   ;; DO-STATIC-FUN
   (inst lw lip null-tn (static-fun-offset 'two-arg-+))
@@ -40,22 +40,18 @@
   (inst j lip)
   (move cfp-tn csp-tn t)
 
-  DO-ADD
+  CHECK-OVERFLOW
+  (inst xor temp1 res x)
+  (inst xor temp2 res y)
+  (inst and temp temp1 temp2)
+  (inst bgez temp DONE)
+
+  ;; We did overflow, so do the bignum version
+  (inst sra temp1 x n-fixnum-tag-bits)
   (inst sra temp2 y n-fixnum-tag-bits)
   (inst addu temp temp1 temp2)
-  ;; check for overflow
-  (inst sra temp1 temp (- n-word-bits n-lowtag-bits))
-  (inst beq temp1 RETURN)
-  (inst nor temp1 temp1)
-  (inst beq temp1 RETURN)
-  (inst nop)
   (with-fixed-allocation (res pa-flag temp2 bignum-widetag (1+ bignum-digits-offset))
     (storew temp res bignum-digits-offset other-pointer-lowtag))
-  (inst b DONE)
-  (inst nop)
-
-  RETURN
-  (inst sll res temp n-fixnum-tag-bits)
 
   DONE)

title: cases and record updates
Test Monad
contents:
module Main where

import Monad

data CounterMonad a = CounterMonad a

instance Monad CounterMonad where
    return c                 = CounterMonad c
    (CounterMonad c) >>= k   = k c

incrementCounter c = CounterMonad $ c+1
readCounter c      = CounterMonad c
clearCounter c     = CounterMonad 0

main = return 0         >>=
       incrementCounter >>=
       incrementCounter >>=
       readCounter      >>= \c ->
       putStrLn $ show $ c

#!/home/tkxue/bin/scsh \
-lm /home/tkxue/emacs/scm/package.scm -o tkx-util -o tkx-output -o tkx-processor -o tkx-cutil -s
!#

(if (not (= (length (command-line))
	    2))
    (die "Fatal: takes exactly one argument."))
  
(define (convert in-file)
  (let ((file (map (lambda (x)
		     (c-file-processor 'process x))
		   (list-from-file in-file))))
    (reduce string-append "\n"
	    (map (lambda (x)
		   (reduce string-append "" x))
		 (reverse file)))))
		   
(let* ((filename (cadr (command-line)))
       (in-file (open-input-file (string-append filename ".x")))
       (out-file (open-output-file (string-append filename ".h"))))
  (format out-file "#ifndef H_~A\n#define H_~A\n" filename filename)
  (write-string (convert in-file) out-file)
  (format out-file "#endif\n"))

title: NSOpenPanel weirdness
mini-rant
contents:
The article at http://docs.info.apple.com/article.html?artnum=303602 contains some very poor information. Some of which is very bad considering Apple's recent marketing ads.

Step 3, Name your children:

"Untitled folder 8, Word027.doc, DSC_1366.jpgyou've probably got a few (or way more than a few) files and folders that you've felt less than inspired to properly name. Then suddenly you need to pluck that prized picture from your ginormous collection of DSC_0001.jpg to DSC_1400.jpg named filesif you only knew which number it was. Go through your generically-named files and folders and give them more descriptive names so you can find what you need fast (though it can find files quickly, Spotlight won't find your tabloid-ready Bigfoot picture if you left the file alone with its cryptic camera-given name)."

You cannot do this for Image files. Since Apple advertises iPhoto everywhere and it's for managing photos, then you can't rename these files in the finder. While I'm not sure if iPhoto uses aliases for tracking files, I know very well that the AlbumData.xml does not. It uses hardcoded paths. Things like iMovie, iWeb, and other third party applications (like TiVo) read this file to get the paths to images. If you rename the files without launching iPhoto and forcing an update of this file, you won't be able to use any of these images as you have before.

All the image renames should be done in iPhoto or whatever photo manager you use. Furthermore, if you properly tag the files in iPhoto, you can use spotlight to search them without having to rename the files.

"4) Prune Through Your File Forest 
To reduce the amount of clutter on your hard drive, free up some disk space by archiving large, seldom used files (learn how here), and be sure to name the resulting archive file appropriately too, so you know what's in it. Delete any unnecessary or outdated personal files whenever possible and anything that you no longer want or needjust drag them all into the Trash and don't forget to empty it. Be brave. Your computer will reward you with improved performance."

This is just wrong as of tiger, for the most part. Since tiger uses hot-file adaptive clustering to move frequently used files to faster portions of the HD, the unused, unloved ones will just eventually be moved to the slower part of the disk, doing nothing to performance. If you're one of those that believes "hitting" your hard drive too much is a bad thing, then doing all this archiving will just make it die sooner (if you believe that).

"5) Repair Disk Permissions 
It's a good idea to make sure that your disk permissions are in good working order on a regular basisespecially after upgrading or installing new software. Open Disk Utility (find it in /Applications/Utilities) and select your hard disk icon in the left pane. Click the First Aid tab, then click Repair Disk Permissions to start the process, which can take a few minutes to complete. If Disk Utility finds any issues, it'll fix them along the way."

This is just completely and utterly useless and a waste of time. It prevents nothing and just ends up wasting time you could be spending doing something else. But you already knew I was going to say that. It's almost like this recent update was to personally bait me into saying that...

"6) Back Up Your Files 
To prevent losing your prized or important files, make it a point to back up your keepsakes on a regular basis. You can back up files onto a CD, DVD, external hard drive, iPod, iDisk, or other storage medium and then delete the copies on your hard drive to free up some space. To learn how to back up files, choose Mac Help from the Help menu in the Finder and do a search for back up files. To get some ideas of what and what not to back up, see this page."

That should be number one and 6 and 10.

"7) Restart Your Computer Every Once in a While 
While your Mac can happily hum along 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, you should restart it every once in a while to refresh the system if you're in the habit of keeping your computer running all day and night. This can help clear issues before they arise."

Uhm. No. Mac OS X is designed to run 24 hours a day, 8 days a week. If something fails, it's a bug. Especially since OS X has periodic cleanup jobs it does.. periodically. Suggesting that OS X isn't stable enough to be used for a long time isn't very good for marketing, is it?

"8) Check for Viruses 
Macs don't get anywhere near the amount of viruses that Windows PCs are prone to, but that doesn't mean that they can't get infected. If you don't already have antivirus software, you may want to consider making a purchase. If you have the software installed, be sure to keep your virus definitions up to dateyou can find the latest updates on your software manufacturer's website."

Even though this takes a jab at Windows, it's still saying there's a security problem with OS X that just doesn't exist. It makes it sound as if OS X has the same viral problems as windows. While there has never been an active infection for OS X, just a few lame concepts that didn't work too well.

The only thing a virus checker will tell you is how many Windows viruses you have in your mailbox from spam emails.

"9) Optimize Your Hard Drive 
To ensure the best system performance and keep file damage to an all-time low, optimize your hard drive once a year. Third-party utilities such as Alsoft Disk Warrior Optimizer and Micromat Tech Tool Pro will defragment and optimize your drive."

Now this is completely useless. Again, it's making it sound like OS X isn't stable. When 10.4 has things like auto-defragging, hot file adaptive clustering, and the pre-allocation of blocks to reduce disk problems. In fact, because of these things optimizing your HD could actually slow down some operations as they completely undo all the optimizations OS X itself has done to the HD.

All in all, this seems like a very poorly written article that makes OS X sound buggy, unstable, and a security risk.

title: init script de base (Oexal)
contents:
#!/bin/sh
# Demonstration: scripte de type init ala Debian
#

case "$1" in
  start)
        echo "Starting service..."
        start-stop-daemon [opts] [args]
        ;;
  stop)
        echo "Stopping service..."
        start-stop-daemon [opts] [args]
        ;;

  restart)
        echo "Confusing service..."
        start-stop-daemon [opts] [args]
        ;;

  *)
        echo "Usage: /etc/init.d/`basename $0` {start|stop|restart}"
        exit 1
esac

exit 0

title: attempt at splitting a path
contents:
(let ((path "/foo/bar/baz"))
  (let (base collection filename)
    (save-match-data
      (if (not (string-match "\\(.*\\)/\\(.*\\)" path))
          nil
        (setq collection (match-string 1 path))
        (setq filename (match-string 2 path))))
    (list base collection filename)))

=> (nil "/foo/bar" "baz")

title: simplify-pathname
contents:
(defun simplify-pathname (path)
  (let* ((components (last (split-string path "/") 2))
	 (dir (first components))
	 (file (second components)))
    (concat dir "/" file)))

(simplify-pathname  "/share/music/bo/FooBar/foobarfoobarfoobarfoobarfoobarfoobarfoobarfoobar/Foobar.mp3")

(add-hook 'rcirc-receive-message-hooks 'notify-if-nick)

(defun notify-if-nick (process command sender args line)
  (if (string-match rcirc-nick line)
      (shell-command (concat "notify-send \"" sender " said\" \"" line "\""))))

title: primitive montezuma example
contents:
(in-package #:montezuma)

(defvar *paste-index* nil)

(defun index-pastes (pastes)
  (setf *paste-index* (make-instance 'index
				     :default-field "contents"))
  (dolist (paste pastes)
    (let ((doc (make-instance 'document)))
      ;; I'm just using the paste format as returned by
      ;; paste.lisp.org's XML-RPC API.
      (let ((number   (make-field "number"   (format nil "~S" (elt paste 0)) :stored T :index :untokenized))
	    (user     (make-field "user"     (elt paste 2) :index :untokenized))
	    (channel  (make-field "channel"  (elt paste 3) :index :untokenized))
	    (title    (make-field "title"    (elt paste 4) :stored T :index :tokenized))
	    (contents (make-field "contents" (elt paste 6) :index :tokenized)))
	(add-field doc number)
	(add-field doc user)
	(add-field doc channel)
	(add-field doc title)
	(add-field doc contents)
	(add-document-to-index *paste-index* doc)))))

(defun search-pastes (field words)
  (let ((query (make-instance 'boolean-query)))
    (dolist (word words)
      (add-query query
		 (make-instance 'term-query
				:term (make-term field word))
		 :must-occur))
    (search-each *paste-index* query
		 #'(lambda (doc score)
		     (let ((paste (get-document *paste-index* doc)))
		       (format T "~&Score: ~5,2F  Paste: ~A (~S)"
			       score
			       (field-data (document-field paste "number"))
			       (field-data (document-field paste "title"))))))))

	set targetHeaderFile to associated file name of window 1 of active project document
	
	-- Extract the leaf
	set savedDelims to AppleScript's text item delimiters
	set AppleScript's text item delimiters to "/"
	set pathItems to text items of targetHeaderFile
	set AppleScript's text item delimiters to savedDelims
	set leafName to last item of pathItems
	
	-- Construct an include text
	set includeLine to "#import \"" & leafName & "\"" & "
"
	
	-- Copy it to the pasteboard
	set the clipboard to includeLine
end tell

title: son
contents:
(require (planet "htmlprag.ss" ("neil" "htmlprag.plt"))
	 (lib "pregexp.ss")
         (lib "url.ss" "net")
         (lib "uri-codec.ss" "net")
	 (lib "head.ss" "net")
         (lib "plt-match.ss"))

(define URL "http://www.sexyono.com/conoceme/")
(define COOKIE '(("sel_os" . "h")
                 ("sel_CodigoPais" . "14")
                 ("sel_geoMode" . "ON")
                 ("sel_age" . "1")
                 ("sel_sex" . "f")
                 ("sel_CodigoProvincia" . "933")))

;; make-cookie-header : cookie -> string
;; a partir de los datos dados, crea una cadena que representa una cookie
;; lista para mandarla al servidor
(define (make-cookie-header cookie-data)
  (string-append "Cookie: $Version=0;"
                  (pregexp-replace* "(?<=; *)[Pp]ath" cookie-data "$Path")))

;; make-cookie : assoc (string string) -> string
;; crea una cadena de cookie a partir de una alist
(define (alist->cookie al)
  (let* ([format-field
          (lambda (name val)
            (string-append 
             (form-urlencoded-encode name)
             "="
             (form-urlencoded-encode val)))]
         [strs (let loop ([al al])
                 (cond
                   [(null? al) '()]
                   [(null? (cdr al)) (list (format-field (caar al)
                                                         (cdar al)))]
                   [else (list* (format-field (caar al) (cdar al))
                                ";"
                                (loop (cdr al)))]))])
    (apply string-append strs)))

;; cookie-header->data : string -> string
;; remueve los CRLF de una cadena de cookie obtenida del servidor
(define (cookie-header->data cookie-header)
  (and cookie-header
       (pregexp-replace "\r\n" cookie-header "")))

;; do-post : url-string alist alist -> (list sxml cookie)
;; hace un POST en url, llenando los valores que hay en fields/vals
;; usando el contenido de cookie como Cookie
(define (do-post url fields/vals cookie)
  (with-handlers ((exn:fail:network?
                   (lambda (exn)
                     (cerr "Error al conectarse con '~a'." url)
                     #f)))
    (let* ([str-lst (if cookie
                      (list (make-cookie-header (alist->cookie cookie))
                            "Connection: close")
                      (list "Connection: close"))]
           [vals (if fields/vals
                   (string->bytes/utf-8 (alist->form-urlencoded fields/vals))
                   #"")]
           [port (post-impure-port (string->url url) vals str-lst)]
           [header (purify-port port)]
           [set-cookie (cookie-header->data
                        (extract-field "Set-Cookie" header))]
           [xexpr (html->sxml port)])
      (close-input-port port)
      (list xexpr set-cookie))))

;; make-extractor : pattern result -> (sxml -> res)
;; crea una función que toma un sxml como argumento, la matchea con pattern
;; y si tiene éxito, regresa result (sacado de pattern)
(define-syntax make-extractor
  (syntax-rules ()
    [(_ pattern result)
     (letrec ([extract (lambda (sxml)
                         (match sxml
                           [pattern result]
                           [`(,elt (... ...)) (ormap extract sxml)]
                           [else #f]))])
       extract)]))

;; extract-permalink : sxml -> url-string
;; extrae el permalink del sxml
(define extract-permalink
  (make-extractor
   `(td (@ (align "center"))
        (div (@ (class "log")) "Puedes compartir esta foto con el siguiente link:")
        ,_ ,_
        (b (@ (class "ro")) ,permalink))
   permalink))

;; extract-comment : sxml -> string
;; extrae el comment del sxml
(define extract-comment
  (make-extractor
   `(td (@ (align "left") (style "padding: 4px")) ,comment)
   comment))

;; extract-picture-link : sxml -> url-string
;; extrae el link a la foto del sxml
(define extract-picture-link
  (make-extractor
   `(td (@ (align "center"))
        (img (@ (src ,picture-link) (alt "Conocer gente"))))
   picture-link))

(define (get-data)
  (let ([sxml (car (do-post URL #f COOKIE))])
    (list (extract-permalink sxml)
          (extract-comment sxml)
          (extract-picture-link sxml))))

;; (thread thunk)
;; (make-channel)
;; (channel-get channel)
;; (channel-put channel v)

title: find hashtable maximizing key with loop
contents:
(defparameter *ht* (make-hash-table :test 'eql))

(setf (gethash 10 *ht*) 42)
(setf (gethash 11 *ht*) 40)
(setf (gethash 9 *ht*) 41)

(loop for key being the hash-keys of *ht* 
      using (hash-value value) 
      with max-key = nil and max-value = nil
      finally (return max-key) do
      (when (or (not max-value) (> value max-value))
        (setf max-value value
              max-key key)))

  (when (executable-find "amixer")
    (defun amixer-frob-master (var)
      "Does something to the amixer master volume"
      (start-process "mixer" nil "amixer" "sset" "Master" var))
    (defun amixer-raise-volume ()
      "Increase volume by 4%"
      (interactive)
      (amixer-frob-master "4%+"))
    (defun amixer-lower-volume ()
      "Decrease volume by 4%"
      (interactive)
      (amixer-frob-master "4%-"))
    (define-key emms-playlist-mode-map (kbd "-") 'amixer-lower-volume)
    (define-key emms-playlist-mode-map (kbd "+") 'amixer-raise-volume)
    )
  (defun emms-startup ()
    "Do personal emms startup."
    (interactive)
    ;(emms-playlist-mode-open-buffer "~/mp3/emms4.list")
    (emms-play-playlist "~/mp3/emms4.list")
    (emms-playlist-mode-go)
    (bury-buffer)
    (use-if-available
     'protect-buffer-from-kill-mode nil
     (get-buffer emms-playlist-buffer-name)
     )
    )
  (defun emms-track-description-aiviru-simple (track)
    "Simple function to give a user-readable description of a track.
If it's a file track, just return the file name.
Otherwise, return the type and the name with a colon in between."
    (if (eq 'file (emms-track-type track))
        (file-name-sans-extension (file-name-nondirectory (emms-track-name track)))
      (concat (symbol-name (emms-track-type track))
              ":"
              (emms-track-name track))))

  (defun emms-track-description-aiviru (track)
    "Return a description of the current track."
    (let ((artist (emms-track-get track 'info-artist))
          (title (emms-track-get track 'info-title)))
      (if (and artist title)
          (format "%s - %s" artist title)
        (emms-track-description-aiviru-simple track))))

  (setq emms-track-description-function 'emms-track-description-aiviru)

  )

title: butt
contents:
module Butt () where

import Maybe
import List

type Term = (Double,Double)
type Polynomial = [Term]

simplify :: Polynomial -> Polynomial
simplify p = foldl (\ p (a,n) ->
                        case find (\ (b,m) -> n == m) p of
                          (Just x)  -> (a+fst x,n) : delete x p
                          Nothing   -> (a,n):p)
             [] p

title: AC_INIT, from the autoconf manual
contents:
- Macro: AC_INIT (PACKAGE, VERSION, [BUG-REPORT], [TARNAME])
     Process any command-line arguments and perform various
     initializations and verifications.

     Set the name of the PACKAGE and its VERSION.  These are typically
     used in `--version' support, including that of `configure'.  The
     optional argument BUG-REPORT should be the email to which users
     should send bug reports.  The package TARNAME differs from
     PACKAGE: the latter designates the full package name (e.g., `GNU
     Autoconf'), while the former is meant for distribution tar ball
     names (e.g., `autoconf').  It defaults to PACKAGE with `GNU '
     stripped, lower-cased, and all characters other than alphanumerics
     and underscores are changed to `-'.

     It is preferable that the arguments of `AC_INIT' be static, i.e.,
     there should not be any shell computation, but they can be
     computed by M4.

--- FindKDE4Internal.cmake      (revision 537451)
+++ FindKDE4Internal.cmake      (working copy)
@@ -500,24 +500,46 @@
 
   set ( _KDE4_PLATFORM_DEFINITIONS -D__APPLE_KDE__ )
 
-  # we need to set MACOSX_DEPLOYMENT_TARGET to (I believe) at least 10.2 or maybe 10.3 to allow
-  # -undefined dynamic_lookup; in the future we should do this programmatically

+  EXEC_PROGRAM("sw_vers | grep ProductVersion | sed -e 's,.*ProductVersion:[[:space:]]*,,' | cut -d. -f1-2" OUTPUT_VARIABLE MACOSX_DEPLOYMENT_TARGET)
+  set (ENV{MACOSX_DEPLOYMENT_TARGET} ${MACOSX_DEPLOYMENT_TARGET})
 
-  # "-undefined dynamic_lookup" means we don't care about missing symbols at link-time by default
-  # this is bad, but unavoidable until there is the equivalent of libtool -no-undefined implemented

(defun eobby-document-record (doc-id args)
  (setq user-id (pop args))
  (setq version (pop args))
  (setq zero (pop args))
  (setq command (pop args))
  (cond
    ((equal "ins" command) (eobby-document-record-ins doc-id args))
    ((equal "del" command) (eobby-document-record-del doc-id args))))

title: more compiler hackery
contents:
the error is:

The variable SB-C:DERIVE-TYPE is unbound.


(handler-bind ((simple-error #'continue))
  (sb-c:defknown mref4 (t t &rest sb-c::index) t
                 (sb-c:flushable sb-c:movable)))

(defoptimizer (mref4 sb-c::derive-type) ((matrix array &rest indices) node)
  (assert-array-rank array (length indices))
  (extract-upgraded-element-type array))

(macrolet ((with-row-major-index ((matrix array indices index &optional new-value)
                                  &rest body)
             `(let (n-indices dims (mt (clem::element-type (sb-c::classoid-pcl-class (sb-c::lvar-type matrix)))))
                (dotimes (i (length ,indices))
                  (push (make-symbol (format nil "INDEX-~D" i)) n-indices)
                  (push (make-symbol (format nil "DIM-~D" i)) dims))
                (setf n-indices (nreverse n-indices))
                (setf dims (nreverse dims))
                `(lambda (,',matrix ,',array ,@n-indices
                          ,@',(when new-value (list new-value)))
                   (declare (ignorable ,',matrix)
                            (type (simple-array ,mt (* *)) ,',array))
                   (let* (,@(let ((,index -1))
                                 (mapcar (lambda (name)
                                           `(,name (array-dimension
                                                    ,',array
                                                    ,(incf ,index))))
                                         dims))
                          (,',index
                           ,(if (null dims)
                                0
                                (do* ((dims dims (cdr dims))
                                      (indices n-indices (cdr indices))
                                      (last-dim nil (car dims))
                                      (form `(sb-kernel::%check-bound ,',array
                                                                      ,(car dims)
                                                                      ,(car indices))
                                            `(sb-kernel::truly-the
                                              sb-kernel::index
                                              (+ (sb-kernel::truly-the sb-kernel::index
                                                                       (* ,form
                                                                          ,last-dim))
                                                 (sb-kernel::%check-bound
                                                  ,',array
                                                  ,(car dims)
                                                  ,(car indices))))))
                                     ((null (cdr dims)) form)))))
                     ,',@body)))))

  (sb-c:deftransform mref4 ((matrix array &rest indices))
    (with-row-major-index
        (matrix array indices index)
      (sb-kernel::hairy-data-vector-ref
       array
       (sb-ext:truly-the sb-kernel::index index)))))

title: because I wanted to do things like these
contents:
(dolist (test-case '((:real . sb-impl::*schedule-real*)
		       (:virtual . sb-impl::*schedule-virtual*)
		       (:profile . sb-impl::*schedule-profile*)))
  (with-test (:name (:timer :relative (car test-case)))
    (let* ((has-run-p nil)
	   (timer (make-timer (lambda () (setq has-run-p t))
			      :name "simple timer"
			      :kind (car test-case))))
      (schedule-timer timer 0.5)
      (sleep 0.2)
      (assert (not has-run-p))
      (sleep 0.5)
      (assert has-run-p)
      (assert (zerop (length (sb-impl::%pqueue-contents (cdr test-case))))))))

title: Fix me!
fun with macros
contents:
I'm trying to eliminate the need to explicitly pass in the element-type to my with-typed-matrix-vals macro. I'd like to be able to use the declared type of x, which we know when with-typed-matrix-vals gets expanded, but I can't seem to get at it.

Suggestions?

===

(in-package :clem-test)

(defmacro with-typed-matrix-vals ((m element-type a) &body body)
  ;;; (print (clem::element-type (class-of m)))
  `(let ((,a (clem::matrix-vals ,m)))
     (declare (type (simple-array ,element-type (* *)) ,a))
     ,@body))

(defun matrix-bench/ub8-matrix-add-wtv ()
  (let ((x (make-instance 'ub8-matrix :rows 2048 :cols 2048 :initial-element 1)))
    (declare (type ub8-matrix x))
    (let ((acc 0)
          (rows (rows x))
          (cols (cols x)))
      (declare (type (unsigned-byte 32) acc)
               (type fixnum rows cols))
      (clem-test::with-typed-matrix-vals (x (unsigned-byte 8) v)
        (dotimes (i rows)
          (declare (type fixnum i))
          (dotimes (j cols)
            (declare (type fixnum j))
            (setf acc (+ acc (the (unsigned-byte 8) (clem::aref v i j)))))))
      (print acc))))

title: Type checking issues
contents:
mapPredM :: (Eq a, Monad m) => (Pred a -> m (Pred a)) -> Pred a -> m (Pred a)
mapPredM f x = do y <- case x of
                      PredOr xs  -> fs isTrue predTrue xs >>= return . predOr
                      PredAnd xs -> fs isFalse predFalse xs >>= return . predAnd
                      x -> return x
                  f y
    where
        fs test result xs = case xs of
            [] -> []
            (x:xs) -> do y <- mapPredM f x
                         if test y
                            then return [result]
                            else fs test result xs >>= return . (y:)

isTrue :: Pred a -> Bool
predTrue :: Pred a
PredOr :: [Pred a] -> Pred a
predOr :: [Pred a] -> Pred a

Or/And have same types. True/False have same types.

Hugs:
ERROR file:.\Pred\Type.hs:40 - Inferred type is not general enough
*** Expression    : mapPredM
*** Expected type : (Eq a, Monad b) => (Pred a -> b (Pred a)) -> Pred a -> b (Pred a)
*** Inferred type : (Eq a, Monad []) => (Pred a -> [Pred a]) -> Pred a -> [Pred a]


GHCi:
./Pred/Type.hs:48:25:
    Couldn't match the rigid variable `m' against `[]'
      `m' is bound by the type signature for `mapPredM'
      Expected type: []
      Inferred type: m
    In a 'do' expression: y <- mapPredM f x
    In a case alternative:
        (x : xs)
          -> do
               y <- mapPredM f x
               if test y then return [result] else (fs test result xs) >>= (retu
rn . ((y :)))

title: not-enough-eval problem?
contents:
short context:

about a week ago i asked on #lisp about a (let ..) analog which would
allow me to locally bind (symbol-function ..)`s of symbols.

of course i knew about (flet/labels ..), however they suffer from my 
macroexpansion skills:

(defmacro symfnlet* (fndecllist &body body)
  `(labels (,@(loop for (sym val) in fndecllist
		 collect `(,sym (&rest stuff) (apply ,val stuff))))
     ,@body))

the fletted symbol is evaluated every time it is referenced -- which is the problem

(define (spawn-slime48-tcp-server world exit-on-quit? . port-opt)
  (let ((server (apply spawn-swank-tcp-server world
                       (lambda (session-placeholder body)
                         (with-sldb-handler #f
                           (lambda ()
                             ((lambda (body)
                                (if exit-on-quit?
                                    (with-swank-quitter
                                        (lambda ()
                                          (scheme-exit-now 0))
                                      body)
                                    (body)))
                              (lambda ()
                                (with-slime48-port-redirection
                                    session-placeholder
                                  (lambda (init exit)
                                    (body
                                     (lambda ()
                                       (enable-nested-slime48 world)
                                       (init))
                                     exit))))))))
                       (if (and (pair? port-opt)
                                (number? (car port-opt)))
                           port-opt
                           '()))))
    (if (and (pair? port-opt)
             (string? (car port-opt)))
        (call-with-output-file (car port-opt)
          (lambda (out)
            (write (swank-tcp-server-port-number server)
                   out))))
    server))

title: looks a bit like my new version :-)
contents:
(defun is-whitespace (char)
  (member char '(#\Space #\Tab #\Newline)))

(defun parse (string)
  (let ((start)
        (result '()))
    (loop for i from 0 below (length string) 
          for char across string do
          (if start
              (when (is-whitespace char)
                (push (subseq string start i) result)
                (setf start nil))
            (unless (is-whitespace char)
              (setf start i))))
    (when start (push (subseq string start) result))
    (nreverse result)))

title: Ugly code
contents:
(defun parse (string)
  (loop for char across string
        with in-string = nil
        with result = '()
        with sub = '()
        finally (progn
                  (when (> (length sub) 0)
                    (push (coerce (nreverse sub) 'string) result)
                    (setf sub '()))
                  (setf in-string nil)
                  (return (nreverse result)))
        do (if (member char '(#\Space #\Tab #\Newline))
               (when in-string
                 (when (> (length sub) 0)
                   (push (coerce (nreverse sub) 'string) result)
                   (setf sub '()))
                 (setf in-string nil))
             (progn
               (unless in-string
                 (setf in-string t))
               (push char sub)))))

(defun test-parse ()
  (assert (equalp '() (parse "")))
  (assert (equalp '("a") (parse "a")))
  (assert (equalp '("a") (parse " a")))
  (assert (equalp '("a") (parse " a ")))
  (assert (equalp '("foo") (parse "foo")))
  (assert (equalp '("foo") (parse " foo")))
  (assert (equalp '("foo") (parse "foo ")))
  (assert (equalp '("foo") (parse "foo")))
  (assert (equalp '("foo") (parse " foo ")))
  (assert (equalp '("foo") (parse "  foo  ")))
  (assert (equalp '("foo" "bar") (parse "foo bar")))
  (assert (equalp '("foo" "bar") (parse "   foo bar")))
  (assert (equalp '("foo" "bar") (parse "   foo bar  "))))

contents:
module Main
  where

import Control.Monad
import Data.Char
import Data.List
import System.Console.Readline
import System.IO
import System.Process

-- This initiates the shell gives starting welcome messages and the rest of it
main = do
   hSetBuffering stdin LineBuffering
   putStrLn "Welcome to Haskell Assistive Intelligence SHell  (HAISH)"
   shell2 "/bin/bash"

-- runs shell of selected type
shell2 sType = do
   (inp,out,err,pid) <- runInteractiveCommand sType
   mapM (flip hSetBuffering NoBuffering) [inp,out,err,stdout]
   shell2' inp out err

-- makes prompt and runs commands in shell
shell2' inp out err = do
   s <- readline "hai> " -- read stdin
   case s of
      Nothing -> error "<eof>"
      Just x -> let s' = dropWhile isSpace x
                in do
                    hPutStrLn inp s' -- execute the shell line in the terminal
                    putStr =<< getCont out --output normal output
                    putStr =<< getCont err --output error output
                    hFlush stdout
                    shell2' inp out err -- start shell2' again

getCont hdl = do
   b <- hReady hdl -- make hReady into boolean
   if b
      then do
         char <- hGetChar hdl
         char2 <- getCont hdl
         return (char : char2 )
      else return []
