title: Main.hs
contents:
#!/usr/bin/runghc
module Main (main) where
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--               2D1456, Advanced Functional Programming                    --
--               Mini project: P1.2 Symbolic Integration                    --
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--               Author: Alfonso Acosta Gómez                               --
--               Date:   March-May 2006                                     --
--               e-mail: alfonso.acosta@gmail.com                           --
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-- Description: Toy symbolic simplifier based on the Lisp code included in  -- 
--              Chapter 8 from:                                             --
--               Norvig, "Paradigms of Artificial Intelligence Programming: --
--               Case Studies in Common Lisp", Morgan Kaufmann              --
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-- Module: Main.hs, Main module                                             --
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--  This program is free software; you can redistribute it and/or modify    --
--  it under the terms of the GNU General Public License as published by    --
--  the Free Software Foundation; version 2 of the License.                 --
--                                                                          --
--  This program is distributed in the hope that it will be useful,         --
--  but WITHOUT ANY WARRANTY; without even the implied warranty of          --
--  MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.  See the           --
--  GNU General Public License for more details.                            --
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
import Expr 
import Maybe
import ExprParser 
import Simplify

import Text.ParserCombinators.Parsec (runParser)
import System.Console.SimpleLineEditor
import Control.Monad (when)
import Char(isSpace)
import System.Posix.IO (stdInput)
import System.Posix.Terminal (queryTerminal)
import IO (isEOF)
import qualified Control.Exception as E (catch, Exception (ErrorCall)) 

main :: IO ()
-- Main function
main = do b <- queryTerminal stdInput -- Are we in a terminal?
          when b initialise 
          loop 1 
          when b restore
  where loop n = do l <- myGetLine
                    case l of
                      Just s -> do when (notEmpty s) 
                                        (E.catch (processExpr n s) printError) 
                                   loop (n+1)
                      Nothing -> return () 



printError :: E.Exception -> IO ()
printError (E.ErrorCall str) = putStrLn ("error: "++str)
printError _ = putStrLn "error: Uncatched exception"

myGetLine :: IO (Maybe String)
-- Get a line interactively or not depending on the context
myGetLine = do b <- queryTerminal stdInput
               if b then do l <- getLineEdited "SIMPLIFIER> "
                            case l of
                             Just str -> if str /= ":q" then return (Just str)
                                         else return Nothing  
                             Nothing -> return Nothing
                    else do b <- isEOF
                            if b then return Nothing 
                                 else do l <- getLine
                                         return (Just l)
                                           
 

notEmpty :: String -> Bool
-- A line is valid is not empty
notEmpty str = filter (not.isSpace) beforeComment /= ""
  where beforeComment = fst (break (=='#')  str)

processExpr :: Int -> String -> IO ()
-- Given a lineNumber and a string it processes the expression contained
processExpr n str = case  runParser (lineExprRow n) () "" str of
                          Left err -> putStrLn ("parser error at " ++ 
                                              show err)
                          Right expr -> do --putStr "parsed to: " 
                                           --print expr
                                           --putStr "simplified to: "
                                           print (simplify expr)

title: ExprParser.hs
contents:
module ExprParser (lineExprRow) where
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--               2D1456, Advanced Functional Programming                    --
--               Mini project: P1.2 Symbolic Integration                    --
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--               Author: Alfonso Acosta Gómez                               --
--               Date:   March-May 2006                                     --
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-- Description: Toy symbolic simplifier based on the Lisp code included in  -- 
--              Chapter 8 from:                                             --
--               Norvig, "Paradigms of Artificial Intelligence Programming: --
--               Case Studies in Common Lisp", Morgan Kaufmann              --
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-- Module: ExprParser.hs, Parses an expresion written in text               --
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--  This program is free software; you can redistribute it and/or modify    --
--  it under the terms of the GNU General Public License as published by    --
--  the Free Software Foundation; version 2 of the License.                 --
--                                                                          --
--  This program is distributed in the hope that it will be useful,         --
--  but WITHOUT ANY WARRANTY; without even the implied warranty of          --
--  MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.  See the           --
--  GNU General Public License for more details.                            --
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
import Expr
import Text.ParserCombinators.Parsec
import Text.ParserCombinators.Parsec.Expr
import Text.ParserCombinators.Parsec.Token
import Text.ParserCombinators.Parsec.Language (emptyDef)
import Text.ParserCombinators.Parsec.Pos
import Ratio (approxRational)

instance Read Expr where
  readsPrec _ = either (const []) id . parse lineExpr' ""
    where lineExpr' = do a <- lineExpr
                         rest <- getInput
                         return [(a, rest)]


lang :: TokenParser st
-- Language token parser: permits removing spaces (no newlines) easily
lang  = makeTokenParser emptyDef {commentLine = "#"}

lineExprRow :: Line -> GenParser Char st Expr
-- Parses an expression given a line number
lineExprRow n =  do p <- getPosition
                    setPosition (setSourceLine p n)
                    lineExpr 

lineExpr :: CharParser st Expr
-- Parses an expression from a line removing white spaces at the begining
lineExpr = do whiteSpace lang
              e <- expr
              eof 
              return e

expr :: CharParser st Expr
-- Expression parser
expr    = buildExpressionParser table factor
         <?> "expression"

table :: [[Operator Char st Expr]]
-- Table of operands, for some reason in Norvigs book the operands
-- are Right associative and "/" has a higher precedence than "*"
-- (same goes with "-" and "+")
table = [map (\str -> prefixfun str (Func str)) functions         -- functions
          ,[prefix "-" Negate, prefix "+" id]                  -- unary opers
          ,[op "^" (:^:) AssocRight]                         -- exponent
          ,[op "/" (:/:) AssocRight],[op "*" (:*:) AssocRight] -- / *
          ,[op "-" (:-:) AssocRight],[op "+" (:+:) AssocRight] -- - +
         ]
         where
           op s f assoc
              = Infix (do{ symbol lang s; return f} <?> "operator") assoc
           prefix s f = Prefix (do symbol lang s 
                                   return f
                                <?> "prefix op")
           -- Make sure the function symbols are followed by a separator
           prefixfun s f = Prefix (do try (string s >> followedBySep)
                                      whiteSpace lang
                                      return f
                                   <?> "function")
           consExp lhs rhs = lhs :^: rhs              


followedBySep :: GenParser Char st ()
-- Make sure a function name is followed by a space or opening parentesis)
followedBySep   = notFollowedBy (noneOf "( \v\f\t\r\n")

followedBySepOp :: GenParser Char st ()
-- Make sure a constant symbol is followed by a separator or operator,
-- closing parenthsis or eof
followedBySepOp = (notFollowedBy (noneOf ") \v\f\t\r\n+-/+^") <|> eof)
                  <?> "separator, operator or end of input"                  

functions :: [String]
-- List of valid function identifiers
functions = ["log","exp","sin","cos","tan","sinh","cosh","tanh"]

cSymbols :: [String]
-- List of valid constant symbols
cSymbols = ["e","pi"] 

parseCSymbols :: GenParser Char st Expr
-- parser of valid constant symbols
parseCSymbols = choice (map parseOne cSymbols) 
  where parseOne str = do string str
                          followedBySepOp                                      
                          whiteSpace lang
                          return (CSym str)
                       <?> "csymbol"


parseVar :: GenParser Char st Expr
parseVar = do {c <- lexeme lang letter; return (Var c)}


parseD :: GenParser Char st Expr
-- Parse a Derivative expression (D (cos x) x)
parseD = parseBinary "D" D 

parseI :: GenParser Char st Expr
-- Parse an Integral expression (for example "I (sin x) x")
parseI = parseBinary "I" I 

parseBinary :: String -> (Expr -> Char -> Expr) -> GenParser Char st Expr
-- Parse binary functions of the type "char expression variable"
-- Used for parsing derivatives (D expr var) and integrals (I expr var)
parseBinary s f = do string s
                     followedBySep
                     whiteSpace lang
                     e <- expr
                     -- FIXME: how to check a separator here?
                     --        (expr is a lexem parser, so it runs whiteSpace) 
                     c <- lexeme lang letter
                     return (f e c)
 

factor :: GenParser Char st Expr
-- Parser of a terms included in an expression
factor  =    -- an expression between parens
             parens lang expr
             -- a constant symbol
         <|> parseCSymbols
             -- an integral or a derivative
         <|> parseI <|> parseD
             -- a variable 
         <|> parseVar
             -- a number
         <|> do {e <- naturalOrFloat lang; return (either2const e)}
         <?> "subexpression"

either2const :: Either Integer Double -> Expr
-- transform an either expression into a constant
either2const (Left i)  = Const (fromInteger i)
-- we approximate the float number to a close rational 
-- to avoid things as 0.9 => 8106479329266893 % 9007199254740992
either2const (Right d) = Const (approxRational (realToFrac d) 0.000000001)

title: Simplify.hs
contents:
module Simplify (simplify)  where
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--               2D1456, Advanced Functional Programming                    --
--               Mini project: P1.2 Symbolic Integration                    --
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--               Author: Alfonso Acosta Gómez                               --
--               Date:   March-May 2006                                     --
--               e-mail: alfonso.acosta@gmail.com                           --
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-- Description: Toy symbolic simplifier based on the Lisp code included in  -- 
--              Chapter 8 from:                                             --
--               Norvig, "Paradigms of Artificial Intelligence Programming: --
--               Case Studies in Common Lisp", Morgan Kaufmann              --
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-- Module: Simplify.hs, implements the whole simplifier from the book       --
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--  This program is free software; you can redistribute it and/or modify    --
--  it under the terms of the GNU General Public License as published by    --
--  the Free Software Foundation; version 2 of the License.                 --
--                                                                          --
--  This program is distributed in the hope that it will be useful,         --
--  but WITHOUT ANY WARRANTY; without even the implied warranty of          --
--  MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.  See the           --
--  GNU General Public License for more details.                            --
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
import Expr 
import Maybe

divideFactors :: [Expr] -> [Expr] -> [Expr]
-- Divide a list of factors "numer" (of the form  exp :^: (ExpConst n))
-- by another list of factors "denom"  (of the form  exp :^: (ExpConst n))
-- removing the factors with null exponent
divideFactors numer denom = delZeroExp withZeroExp
  where withZeroExp = foldr (flip divideOne) numer denom  
        -- delZeroEzp removes factors with null exponent 
        delZeroExp = filter (\(_ :^: (Const n)) -> n /= 0) 

divideOne :: [Expr] -> Expr -> [Expr]
-- Divide a list of factors by just one factor
divideOne numer (lhsd :^: Const nd) 
 | numer' == Nothing = (lhsd :^: Const (-nd)) : numer
 | otherwise = fromJust numer' 
  where numer' = querep numer
                     (\ (lhsn :^: _ ) -> lhsn == lhsd) 
                     (\ (lhsn :^: Const nn) -> 
                        (lhsn :^: Const (nn - nd)))
                        


integrate :: Expr -> Char -> Maybe Expr
-- Integrate expr against variable x
-- Basic trivial cases
integrate expr x | freeOf expr x = Just (expr :*: (Var x))
integrate (f :+: g)  x = binIntegrate (f,g) (:+:) x
integrate (f :-: g)  x = binIntegrate (f,g) (:-:) x
integrate expr@(Negate f) x = if isJust f' then Just(Negate(fromJust f'))
                                           else Nothing
  where f' = integrate f x
-- General case
integrate expr x       = 
               if isJust tryxfact 
               then Just (simplify ((unfactorize cfact) :*: fromJust tryxfact))
               else Nothing 
 -- We get the constant factors to take them out of the integral  
 where (cfact,xfact) = partitionIf ((flip freeOf) x) (factorize expr)  
       tryxfact      = intMethods xfact x

binIntegrate :: (Expr, Expr) -> (Expr -> Expr -> Expr) -> Char -> Maybe Expr
-- Auxiliar function of integrate which deals with Maybe constructors
binIntegrate (t1,t2) f x 
 | t1' == Nothing && t2' == Nothing = Nothing
 | otherwise = Just (justOrId t1 t1' `f` justOrId t2 t2') 
  where t1' = integrate t1 x
        t2' = integrate t2 x 
        justOrId a a' = if isJust a' then fromJust a' else a

intMethods :: [Expr] -> Char -> Maybe Expr
-- Applies different integration methods
-- to integrate a factorized expression (list of factors) against x
intMethods [] x = Just(Var x)
-- By now we just have the derivative divides method
intMethods factors x = derivResult   
-- We should be able to add more methods in the future 
   where derivResult  = foldr tryFactor Nothing factors 
         -- tryFactor tries to apply derivate-devides with one of the factors
         -- of the list
           -- no result found so far
         tryFactor factor Nothing = derivDiv factor factors x
           -- a solution was found, we just keep it  
         tryFactor _ (Just solution) = Just solution


         
partitionIf :: (a -> Bool) -> [a] -> ([a], [a])
-- Divides the elements of xs in those that satisfy pred
-- and elements that don't
partitionIf pred = foldr classify ([],[])
 where classify e (xs,ys) = if pred e then (e:xs, ys) else (xs, e:ys)    
        
derivDiv :: Expr -> [Expr] -> Char -> Maybe Expr
-- Derivative divides method
derivDiv  factor@(u :^: (Const n)) factors x
 -- no variables in k::[Expr] 
 | freeOfList k x = 
   if n == -1 then -- -1 as exponent
      Just ( (unfactorize k) :*: (Func "log" u) )
   else
    Just(
      (unfactorize k) :*: (u :^: Const (n+1))
      :/:
      (Const (n+1)))
 -- 1 as exponent, succesful try with table and no variables in k2
 | n == 1 && isJust tryTable && freeOfList k2 x = 
     Just ( (fromJust tryTable) :*: (unfactorize k2) )
 | otherwise = Nothing         
  where k  = divideFactors factors (factorize (factor :*: deriv u x))
        k2 = divideFactors 
              factors 
              (factorize (u :*: deriv (getArg u) x))
        getArg (Func name arg) = arg 
        tryTable = intWithTable u
        
        
intWithTable :: Expr -> Maybe Expr
intWithTable (Func "log"  expr) = Just ( (expr :*: (Func "log" expr)) :-: expr)
intWithTable (Func "exp"  expr) = Just ( Func "exp" expr )
intWithTable (Func "sin"  expr) = Just ( Negate (Func "cos" expr) )
intWithTable (Func "cos"  expr) = Just ( Func "sin" expr )
intWithTable (Func "tan"  expr) = Just ( Negate (Func "log"(Func "cos" expr)) )
intWithTable (Func "sinh" expr) = Just ( Func "cosh" expr )
intWithTable (Func "cosh" expr) = Just ( Func "sinh" expr )
intWithTable (Func "tanh" expr) = Just ( Func "log"(Func "cosh" expr) )
intWithTable _                  = Nothing

simplify :: Expr -> Expr
-- Assures that any compound expression will be simplified
-- by first simplifying the arguments and then calling simplifyExp
-- It is the main function once the expression has been parsed
simplify var@(Var x)     = var 
simplify const@(Const _) = const   
simplify csym@(CSym  _)  = csym
simplify Undefined       = Undefined
simplify (l :+: r)= simpExpr (simplify l :+: simplify r) 
simplify (l :-: r)= simpExpr (simplify l :-: simplify r) 
simplify (l :*: r)= simpExpr (simplify l :*: simplify r) 
simplify (l :/: r)= simpExpr (simplify l :/: simplify r) 
simplify (l :^: r)= simpExpr (simplify l :^: simplify r)
simplify (Negate x) = simpExpr (Negate (simplify x))
simplify (Func n x) = simpExpr (Func n (simplify x)) 
simplify (I    e x) = simpExpr (I (simplify e) x)
simplify (D    e x) = simpExpr (D (simplify e) x)

simpExpr :: Expr -> Expr
-- simplifies a symbolic expression
simpExpr expr
 -- Try with specific simplification functions (such as integration)
 -- | isJust tryFn    = fromJust tryFn
 -- Note: We don't need them because differently from Lisp, we can just 
 -- include our own functions at the begining our pattern matching rules

 -- Try with simplification rules and continue simplifying
 | isJust tryRules = simplify (fromJust tryRules)
 -- Try evaluating the expression in case it is numeric
 -- FIXME: It might be better if we try to numeric-evaluate before using rules 
 --  we don't have the same problem of 'eval' in lisp cause we implement the 
 --  function ourselves and can control the exceptions
 | isJust tryEval  = Const (fromJust tryEval)
 -- give up and return what we got
 | otherwise = expr
   where -- tryFn    = simpByFn expr
         tryRules = simpByRules expr
         tryEval  = simpByEval expr

-- simpByFn :: Expr -> Maybe Expr
-- Simplify by an specific simplification function
-- simpByFn _ = Nothing


simpByRules :: Expr -> Maybe Expr
-- Try to simplify an expression by a table of rules 

--------------
-- Integration
--------------

simpByRules (I expr x) = if isJust tryInt 
                         then Just ((unfactorize.factorize)(fromJust tryInt))
                         else Nothing
 where tryInt = integrate expr x
----------------------
-- General Basic rules
----------------------

-- 0 is neutral with :+: 
simpByRules (expr :+: (Const 0))   = Just expr
simpByRules ((Const 0) :+: expr)   = Just expr
-- a + a = 2 * a
simpByRules (a :+: b) | a == b     = Just ((Const 2) :*: a)
-- 0 is neutral with :-:
simpByRules (expr :-: (Const 0))   = Just expr
simpByRules ((Const 0) :-: expr)   = Just expr
-- a - a = 0
simpByRules (a :-: b) | a == b     = Just (Const 0)
-- added by me
-- (Negate (Const a)) = (Const -a)
simpByRules (Negate (Const a)) = Just (Const (-a))
-- added by me
-- (Negate (Const a)) = (Const -a)
simpByRules (a :-: (Const b)) = Just (a :+: Const (-b))
-- (- - a) = a
simpByRules (Negate (Negate expr)) = Just expr
-- 1 is neutral with :*:
simpByRules ((Const 1) :*: expr)   = Just expr 
simpByRules (expr :*: (Const 1))   = Just expr
-- 0 * a = 0
simpByRules ((Const 0) :*: _)      = Just (Const 0) 
simpByRules (_ :*: (Const 0))      = Just (Const 0)
-- a * a = a ^ 2
simpByRules (a :*: b) | a == b     = Just (a :^: Const 2)
-- a / 0 = undefined
simpByRules (_ :/: (Const 0))      = Just Undefined
-- 0 / a = 0
simpByRules ((Const 0) :/: _)      = Just (Const 0)
-- a / 1 = a 
simpByRules (expr :/: (Const 1))   = Just expr
-- a / a = 1
simpByRules (a :/: b) | a == b     = Just (Const 1)
-- 0 ^ 0 = undefined
simpByRules (Const 0 :^: Const 0)  = Just Undefined
-- a ^ 0 = 1
simpByRules (_ :^: Const 0)  = Just (Const 1)
-- 0 ^ a = 0
simpByRules ((Const 0) :^: _)     = Just (Const 0)
-- 1 ^ a = 1
simpByRules ((Const 1) :^: _)     = Just (Const 1)
-- a ^ 1 = a
simpByRules (expr :^: Const 1) = Just expr
-- a ^ (-1) = 1 / a
simpByRules (expr :^: Const (-1)) = Just ((Const 1) :/: expr)
-- a * (b / a) = b
simpByRules (a :*: (b :/: c)) | a == c = Just b
-- (a / b) * b = a
simpByRules ((a :/: b) :*: c) | b == c = Just a
-- (a * b) / b = a ; (a * b) / a = b 
simpByRules ((a :*: b) :/: c) | b == c = Just a | a == c = Just b
-- a + (-a) = 0
simpByRules (a :+: (Negate b))| a == b = Just (Const 0)
-- (-a) + a = 0
simpByRules ((Negate a) :+: b)| a == b = Just (Const 0)
-- (a + b) - a = b (strange case cause Norvig doesn't try symetric expresions)
simpByRules ((a :+: b) :-: c) | a == c = Just a

------------------------------------------------------------
-- Simplifications regarding associativity and conmutativity
------------------------------------------------------------

-- conmutative inversion s * n = n * s  
simpByRules (a :*: Const b) | notConst a  = Just (Const b :*: a)
-- n * (m * x) = (n * m) * x
simpByRules (Const a :*: (Const b :*: c)) = Just ((Const a :*: Const b) :*: c)
-- x * (n * y) = n * (x * y)
simpByRules (a :*: (Const b :*: c))       = Just (Const b :*: (a :*: c))
-- (n * x) * y = n * (x * y)
simpByRules ((Const a :*: b) :*: c)       = Just (Const a :*: (b :*: c))

-- conmutative inversion n + s = s + n  
simpByRules (Const a :+: b) | notConst b  = Just (b :+: Const a)
-- (x + m) + n = x + (m + n)
simpByRules ((a :+: Const b) :+: Const c) = Just (a :+: (Const b :+: Const c))
-- (x + y) + n = (x + y) + n
simpByRules (a :+: (b :+: Const c))       = Just ((a :+: b) :+: Const c)
-- (x + n) + y = (x + y) + n
simpByRules ((a :+: Const b) :+: c)       = Just ((a :+: c) :*: Const b)

----------------
-- Logs and Trig
----------------

-- log 1 = 0
simpByRules (Func "log" (Const 1))        = Just (Const 0)
-- log 0 = 1
simpByRules (Func "log" (Const 0))        = Just Undefined
-- log e = 1
simpByRules (Func "log" (CSym "e"))       = Just (Const 1)
-- sin 0 = 0
simpByRules (Func "sin" (Const 0))        = Just (Const 0)
-- sin pi = -1
simpByRules (Func "sin" (CSym "pi"))      = Just (Const 0)
-- cos 0 = 1
simpByRules (Func "cos" (Const 0))        = Just (Const 1)
-- cos pi = -1
simpByRules (Func "cos" (CSym "pi"))      = Just (Const (-1))
-- sin (pi / 2) = 1
simpByRules (Func "sin" ((CSym "pi") :/: (Const 2))) = Just (Const 1)
-- cos (pi / 2) = 0
simpByRules (Func "cos" ((CSym "pi") :/: (Const 2))) = Just (Const 0)
-- log (e ^ x) = x
simpByRules (Func "log" (CSym "e" :^: exp))          = Just exp
-- e ^ (log x) = x
simpByRules (CSym "e" :^: Func "log" exp) = Just exp
-- (x ^ y) * (x ^ z) = x ^ (y + z)
simpByRules ((a :^: b) :*: (c :^: d)) | a == c = Just (a :^: (b :+:d))
-- (x ^ y) / (x ^ z) = x ^ (y - z)
simpByRules ((a :^: b) :/: (c :^: d)) | a == c = Just (a :^: (b:-:d))
-- (log x) + (log y) = log (x * y) 
simpByRules ((Func "log" a) :+: (Func "log" b)) = Just (Func "log" (a :*: b)) 
-- (log x) - (log y) = log (x - y) 
simpByRules ((Func "log" a) :-: (Func "log" b)) = Just (Func "log" (a :/: b))
-- (sin x) ^ 2 + (cos x) ^ 2 = 1
simpByRules (((Func "sin" a) :^: Const 2):+:((Func "cos" b) :^: Const 2))
  | a == b = Just (Const 1)


------------------------
-- Differentiation rules
------------------------

-- d x/ d x = 1
simpByRules (D (Var x)   y) | x == y   = Just (Const 1)
-- d (u + v)/ d x = (d u / d x) + (d v / d x) 
simpByRules (D (u :+: v) x)  = Just ((D u x) :+: (D v x))
-- and so on ....
simpByRules (D (u :-: v) x)  = Just ((D u x) :-: (D v x))
simpByRules (D (Negate u) x) = Just (Negate (D u x))
simpByRules (D (u :*: v) x)  = Just ((u :*:(D v x)) :+: (v :*: (D u x)))
simpByRules (D (u :/: v) x)  = 
  Just (((v :*: (D u x)) :-: (u :*: (D v x))) :/: (v :^: Const 2))
-- I had to change the original order of this rule cause this pattern match
-- overlapped with next one (it is a bug in the book as well)
simpByRules (D ((CSym "e") :^: u) x) =  Just (((CSym "e") :^: u) :*: (D u x))
simpByRules (D (u :^: v@(Const n)) x)  =  
  Just ( (v :*: (u :^: (v :-: (Const 1)))) :*: (D u x) ) 
simpByRules (D (u :^: v) x)  =  
  Just ( ((v :*: (u :^: (v :-: (Const 1)))) :*: (D u x))  
         :+: 
         (((u :^: v) :*: (Func "log" u)) :*: (D v x)) )
simpByRules (D (Func "log" u) x) = Just ((D u x) :/: u)
simpByRules (D (Func "sin" u) x) = Just ((Func "cos" u) :*: (D u x))
simpByRules (D (Func "cos" u) x) = Just ((Negate (Func "sin" u)) :*: (D u x))
simpByRules (D u x) | freeOf u x     =  Just (Const 0)

------------------------------------------------------
-- If we reached this point .. we cannot simplify more
------------------------------------------------------

simpByRules _ = Nothing


simpByEval :: Expr -> Maybe Rational
-- Try to evaluate an expression in case it's arithmetic
simpByEval ((Const a) :+: (Const b))    = Just (a + b)
simpByEval ((Const a) :-: (Const b))    = Just (a - b)
simpByEval ((Const a) :*: (Const b))    = Just (a * b)
simpByEval ((Const a) :/: (Const b))    = Just (a/b)
simpByEval ((Const a) :^: Const b) = Just (a <**> b)            
simpByEval (Negate (Const a))           = Just (-a)
simpByEval _                            = Nothing



deriv :: Expr -> Char -> Expr
deriv expr x = simplify (D expr x)

title: Simplify.hs
contents:
module Simplify (simplify)  where
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--               2D1456, Advanced Functional Programming                    --
--               Mini project: P1.2 Symbolic Integration                    --
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--               Author: Alfonso Acosta Gómez                               --
--               Date:   March-May 2006                                     --
--               e-mail: alfonso.acosta@gmail.com                           --
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-- Description: Toy symbolic simplifier based on the Lisp code included in  -- 
--              Chapter 8 from:                                             --
--               Norvig, "Paradigms of Artificial Intelligence Programming: --
--               Case Studies in Common Lisp", Morgan Kaufmann              --
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-- Module: Simplify.hs, implements the whole simplifier from the book       --
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--  This program is free software; you can redistribute it and/or modify    --
--  it under the terms of the GNU General Public License as published by    --
--  the Free Software Foundation; version 2 of the License.                 --
--                                                                          --
--  This program is distributed in the hope that it will be useful,         --
--  but WITHOUT ANY WARRANTY; without even the implied warranty of          --
--  MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.  See the           --
--  GNU General Public License for more details.                            --
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
import Expr 
import Maybe

divideFactors :: [Expr] -> [Expr] -> [Expr]
-- Divide a list of factors "numer" (of the form  exp :^: (ExpConst n))
-- by another list of factors "denom"  (of the form  exp :^: (ExpConst n))
-- removing the factors with null exponent
divideFactors numer denom = delZeroExp withZeroExp
  where withZeroExp = foldr (flip divideOne) numer denom  
        -- delZeroEzp removes factors with null exponent 
        delZeroExp = filter (\(_ :^: (Const n)) -> n /= 0) 

divideOne :: [Expr] -> Expr -> [Expr]
-- Divide a list of factors by just one factor
divideOne numer (lhsd :^: Const nd) 
 | numer' == Nothing = (lhsd :^: Const (-nd)) : numer
 | otherwise = fromJust numer' 
  where numer' = querep numer
                     (\ (lhsn :^: _ ) -> lhsn == lhsd) 
                     (\ (lhsn :^: Const nn) -> 
                        (lhsn :^: Const (nn - nd)))
                        


integrate :: Expr -> Char -> Maybe Expr
-- Integrate expr against variable x
-- Basic trivial cases
integrate expr x | freeOf expr x = Just (expr :*: (Var x))
integrate (f :+: g)  x = binIntegrate (f,g) (:+:) x
integrate (f :-: g)  x = binIntegrate (f,g) (:-:) x
integrate expr@(Negate f) x = if isJust f' then Just(Negate(fromJust f'))
                                           else Nothing
  where f' = integrate f x
-- General case
integrate expr x       = 
               if isJust tryxfact 
               then Just (simplify ((unfactorize cfact) :*: fromJust tryxfact))
               else Nothing 
 -- We get the constant factors to take them out of the integral  
 where (cfact,xfact) = partitionIf ((flip freeOf) x) (factorize expr)  
       tryxfact      = intMethods xfact x

binIntegrate :: (Expr, Expr) -> (Expr -> Expr -> Expr) -> Char -> Maybe Expr
-- Auxiliar function of integrate which deals with Maybe constructors
binIntegrate (t1,t2) f x 
 | t1' == Nothing && t2' == Nothing = Nothing
 | otherwise = Just (justOrId t1 t1' `f` justOrId t2 t2') 
  where t1' = integrate t1 x
        t2' = integrate t2 x 
        justOrId a a' = if isJust a' then fromJust a' else a

intMethods :: [Expr] -> Char -> Maybe Expr
-- Applies different integration methods
-- to integrate a factorized expression (list of factors) against x
intMethods [] x = Just(Var x)
-- By now we just have the derivative divides method
intMethods factors x = derivResult   
-- We should be able to add more methods in the future 
   where derivResult  = foldr tryFactor Nothing factors 
         -- tryFactor tries to apply derivate-devides with one of the factors
         -- of the list
           -- no result found so far
         tryFactor factor Nothing = derivDiv factor factors x
           -- a solution was found, we just keep it  
         tryFactor _ (Just solution) = Just solution


         
partitionIf :: (a -> Bool) -> [a] -> ([a], [a])
-- Divides the elements of xs in those that satisfy pred
-- and elements that don't
partitionIf pred = foldr classify ([],[])
 where classify e (xs,ys) = if pred e then (e:xs, ys) else (xs, e:ys)    
        
derivDiv :: Expr -> [Expr] -> Char -> Maybe Expr
-- Derivative divides method
derivDiv  factor@(u :^: (Const n)) factors x
 -- no variables in k::[Expr] 
 | freeOfList k x = 
   if n == -1 then -- -1 as exponent
      Just ( (unfactorize k) :*: (Func "log" u) )
   else
    Just(
      (unfactorize k) :*: (u :^: Const (n+1))
      :/:
      (Const (n+1)))
 -- 1 as exponent, succesful try with table and no variables in k2
 | n == 1 && isJust tryTable && freeOfList k2 x = 
     Just ( (fromJust tryTable) :*: (unfactorize k2) )
 | otherwise = Nothing         
  where k  = divideFactors factors (factorize (factor :*: deriv u x))
        k2 = divideFactors 
              factors 
              (factorize (u :*: deriv (getArg u) x))
        getArg (Func name arg) = arg 
        tryTable = intWithTable u
        
        
intWithTable :: Expr -> Maybe Expr
intWithTable (Func "log"  expr) = Just ( (expr :*: (Func "log" expr)) :-: expr)
intWithTable (Func "exp"  expr) = Just ( Func "exp" expr )
intWithTable (Func "sin"  expr) = Just ( Negate (Func "cos" expr) )
intWithTable (Func "cos"  expr) = Just ( Func "sin" expr )
intWithTable (Func "tan"  expr) = Just ( Negate (Func "log"(Func "cos" expr)) )
intWithTable (Func "sinh" expr) = Just ( Func "cosh" expr )
intWithTable (Func "cosh" expr) = Just ( Func "sinh" expr )
intWithTable (Func "tanh" expr) = Just ( Func "log"(Func "cosh" expr) )
intWithTable _                  = Nothing

simplify :: Expr -> Expr
-- Assures that any compound expression will be simplified
-- by first simplifying the arguments and then calling simplifyExp
-- It is the main function once the expression has been parsed
simplify var@(Var x)     = var 
simplify const@(Const _) = const   
simplify csym@(CSym  _)  = csym
simplify Undefined       = Undefined
simplify (l :+: r)= simpExpr (simplify l :+: simplify r) 
simplify (l :-: r)= simpExpr (simplify l :-: simplify r) 
simplify (l :*: r)= simpExpr (simplify l :*: simplify r) 
simplify (l :/: r)= simpExpr (simplify l :/: simplify r) 
simplify (l :^: r)= simpExpr (simplify l :^: simplify r)
simplify (Negate x) = simpExpr (Negate (simplify x))
simplify (Func n x) = simpExpr (Func n (simplify x)) 
simplify (I    e x) = simpExpr (I (simplify e) x)
simplify (D    e x) = simpExpr (D (simplify e) x)

simpExpr :: Expr -> Expr
-- simplifies a symbolic expression
simpExpr expr
 -- Try with specific simplification functions (such as integration)
 -- | isJust tryFn    = fromJust tryFn
 -- Note: We don't need them because differently from Lisp, we can just 
 -- include our own functions at the begining our pattern matching rules

 -- Try with simplification rules and continue simplifying
 | isJust tryRules = simplify (fromJust tryRules)
 -- Try evaluating the expression in case it is numeric
 -- FIXME: It might be better if we try to numeric-evaluate before using rules 
 --  we don't have the same problem of 'eval' in lisp cause we implement the 
 --  function ourselves and can control the exceptions
 | isJust tryEval  = Const (fromJust tryEval)
 -- give up and return what we got
 | otherwise = expr
   where -- tryFn    = simpByFn expr
         tryRules = simpByRules expr
         tryEval  = simpByEval expr

-- simpByFn :: Expr -> Maybe Expr
-- Simplify by an specific simplification function
-- simpByFn _ = Nothing


simpByRules :: Expr -> Maybe Expr
-- Try to simplify an expression by a table of rules 

--------------
-- Integration
--------------

simpByRules (I expr x) = if isJust tryInt 
                         then Just ((unfactorize.factorize)(fromJust tryInt))
                         else Nothing
 where tryInt = integrate expr x
----------------------
-- General Basic rules
----------------------

-- 0 is neutral with :+: 
simpByRules (expr :+: (Const 0))   = Just expr
simpByRules ((Const 0) :+: expr)   = Just expr
-- a + a = 2 * a
simpByRules (a :+: b) | a == b     = Just ((Const 2) :*: a)
-- 0 is neutral with :-:
simpByRules (expr :-: (Const 0))   = Just expr
simpByRules ((Const 0) :-: expr)   = Just expr
-- a - a = 0
simpByRules (a :-: b) | a == b     = Just (Const 0)
-- added by me
-- (Negate (Const a)) = (Const -a)
simpByRules (Negate (Const a)) = Just (Const (-a))
-- added by me
-- (Negate (Const a)) = (Const -a)
simpByRules (a :-: (Const b)) = Just (a :+: Const (-b))
-- (- - a) = a
simpByRules (Negate (Negate expr)) = Just expr
-- 1 is neutral with :*:
simpByRules ((Const 1) :*: expr)   = Just expr 
simpByRules (expr :*: (Const 1))   = Just expr
-- 0 * a = 0
simpByRules ((Const 0) :*: _)      = Just (Const 0) 
simpByRules (_ :*: (Const 0))      = Just (Const 0)
-- a * a = a ^ 2
simpByRules (a :*: b) | a == b     = Just (a :^: Const 2)
-- a / 0 = undefined
simpByRules (_ :/: (Const 0))      = Just Undefined
-- 0 / a = 0
simpByRules ((Const 0) :/: _)      = Just (Const 0)
-- a / 1 = a 
simpByRules (expr :/: (Const 1))   = Just expr
-- a / a = 1
simpByRules (a :/: b) | a == b     = Just (Const 1)
-- 0 ^ 0 = undefined
simpByRules (Const 0 :^: Const 0)  = Just Undefined
-- a ^ 0 = 1
simpByRules (_ :^: Const 0)  = Just (Const 1)
-- 0 ^ a = 0
simpByRules ((Const 0) :^: _)     = Just (Const 0)
-- 1 ^ a = 1
simpByRules ((Const 1) :^: _)     = Just (Const 1)
-- a ^ 1 = a
simpByRules (expr :^: Const 1) = Just expr
-- a ^ (-1) = 1 / a
simpByRules (expr :^: Const (-1)) = Just ((Const 1) :/: expr)
-- a * (b / a) = b
simpByRules (a :*: (b :/: c)) | a == c = Just b
-- (a / b) * b = a
simpByRules ((a :/: b) :*: c) | b == c = Just a
-- (a * b) / b = a ; (a * b) / a = b 
simpByRules ((a :*: b) :/: c) | b == c = Just a | a == c = Just b
-- a + (-a) = 0
simpByRules (a :+: (Negate b))| a == b = Just (Const 0)
-- (-a) + a = 0
simpByRules ((Negate a) :+: b)| a == b = Just (Const 0)
-- (a + b) - a = b (strange case cause Norvig doesn't try symetric expresions)
simpByRules ((a :+: b) :-: c) | a == c = Just a

------------------------------------------------------------
-- Simplifications regarding associativity and conmutativity
------------------------------------------------------------

-- conmutative inversion s * n = n * s  
simpByRules (a :*: Const b) | notConst a  = Just (Const b :*: a)
-- n * (m * x) = (n * m) * x
simpByRules (Const a :*: (Const b :*: c)) = Just ((Const a :*: Const b) :*: c)
-- x * (n * y) = n * (x * y)
simpByRules (a :*: (Const b :*: c))       = Just (Const b :*: (a :*: c))
-- (n * x) * y = n * (x * y)
simpByRules ((Const a :*: b) :*: c)       = Just (Const a :*: (b :*: c))

-- conmutative inversion n + s = s + n  
simpByRules (Const a :+: b) | notConst b  = Just (b :+: Const a)
-- (x + m) + n = x + (m + n)
simpByRules ((a :+: Const b) :+: Const c) = Just (a :+: (Const b :+: Const c))
-- (x + y) + n = (x + y) + n
simpByRules (a :+: (b :+: Const c))       = Just ((a :+: b) :+: Const c)
-- (x + n) + y = (x + y) + n
simpByRules ((a :+: Const b) :+: c)       = Just ((a :+: c) :*: Const b)

----------------
-- Logs and Trig
----------------

-- log 1 = 0
simpByRules (Func "log" (Const 1))        = Just (Const 0)
-- log 0 = 1
simpByRules (Func "log" (Const 0))        = Just Undefined
-- log e = 1
simpByRules (Func "log" (CSym "e"))       = Just (Const 1)
-- sin 0 = 0
simpByRules (Func "sin" (Const 0))        = Just (Const 0)
-- sin pi = -1
simpByRules (Func "sin" (CSym "pi"))      = Just (Const 0)
-- cos 0 = 1
simpByRules (Func "cos" (Const 0))        = Just (Const 1)
-- cos pi = -1
simpByRules (Func "cos" (CSym "pi"))      = Just (Const (-1))
-- sin (pi / 2) = 1
simpByRules (Func "sin" ((CSym "pi") :/: (Const 2))) = Just (Const 1)
-- cos (pi / 2) = 0
simpByRules (Func "cos" ((CSym "pi") :/: (Const 2))) = Just (Const 0)
-- log (e ^ x) = x
simpByRules (Func "log" (CSym "e" :^: exp))          = Just exp
-- e ^ (log x) = x
simpByRules (CSym "e" :^: Func "log" exp) = Just exp
-- (x ^ y) * (x ^ z) = x ^ (y + z)
simpByRules ((a :^: b) :*: (c :^: d)) | a == c = Just (a :^: (b :+:d))
-- (x ^ y) / (x ^ z) = x ^ (y - z)
simpByRules ((a :^: b) :/: (c :^: d)) | a == c = Just (a :^: (b:-:d))
-- (log x) + (log y) = log (x * y) 
simpByRules ((Func "log" a) :+: (Func "log" b)) = Just (Func "log" (a :*: b)) 
-- (log x) - (log y) = log (x - y) 
simpByRules ((Func "log" a) :-: (Func "log" b)) = Just (Func "log" (a :/: b))
-- (sin x) ^ 2 + (cos x) ^ 2 = 1
simpByRules (((Func "sin" a) :^: Const 2):+:((Func "cos" b) :^: Const 2))
  | a == b = Just (Const 1)


------------------------
-- Differentiation rules
------------------------

-- d x/ d x = 1
simpByRules (D (Var x)   y) | x == y   = Just (Const 1)
-- d (u + v)/ d x = (d u / d x) + (d v / d x) 
simpByRules (D (u :+: v) x)  = Just ((D u x) :+: (D v x))
-- and so on ....
simpByRules (D (u :-: v) x)  = Just ((D u x) :-: (D v x))
simpByRules (D (Negate u) x) = Just (Negate (D u x))
simpByRules (D (u :*: v) x)  = Just ((u :*:(D v x)) :+: (v :*: (D u x)))
simpByRules (D (u :/: v) x)  = 
  Just (((v :*: (D u x)) :-: (u :*: (D v x))) :/: (v :^: Const 2))
-- I had to change the original order of this rule cause this pattern match
-- overlapped with next one (it is a bug in the book as well)
simpByRules (D ((CSym "e") :^: u) x) =  Just (((CSym "e") :^: u) :*: (D u x))
simpByRules (D (u :^: v@(Const n)) x)  =  
  Just ( (v :*: (u :^: (v :-: (Const 1)))) :*: (D u x) ) 
simpByRules (D (u :^: v) x)  =  
  Just ( ((v :*: (u :^: (v :-: (Const 1)))) :*: (D u x))  
         :+: 
         (((u :^: v) :*: (Func "log" u)) :*: (D v x)) )
simpByRules (D (Func "log" u) x) = Just ((D u x) :/: u)
simpByRules (D (Func "sin" u) x) = Just ((Func "cos" u) :*: (D u x))
simpByRules (D (Func "cos" u) x) = Just ((Negate (Func "sin" u)) :*: (D u x))
simpByRules (D u x) | freeOf u x     =  Just (Const 0)

------------------------------------------------------
-- If we reached this point .. we cannot simplify more
------------------------------------------------------

simpByRules _ = Nothing


simpByEval :: Expr -> Maybe Rational
-- Try to evaluate an expression in case it's arithmetic
simpByEval ((Const a) :+: (Const b))    = Just (a + b)
simpByEval ((Const a) :-: (Const b))    = Just (a - b)
simpByEval ((Const a) :*: (Const b))    = Just (a * b)
simpByEval ((Const a) :/: (Const b))    = Just (a/b)
simpByEval ((Const a) :^: Const b) = Just (a <**> b)            
simpByEval (Negate (Const a))           = Just (-a)
simpByEval _                            = Nothing



deriv :: Expr -> Char -> Expr
deriv expr x = simplify (D expr x)

title: ExprParser.hs
contents:
module ExprParser (lineExprRow) where
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--               2D1456, Advanced Functional Programming                    --
--               Mini project: P1.2 Symbolic Integration                    --
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--               Author: Alfonso Acosta Gómez                               --
--               Date:   March-May 2006                                     --
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-- Description: Toy symbolic simplifier based on the Lisp code included in  -- 
--              Chapter 8 from:                                             --
--               Norvig, "Paradigms of Artificial Intelligence Programming: --
--               Case Studies in Common Lisp", Morgan Kaufmann              --
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-- Module: ExprParser.hs, Parses an expresion written in text               --
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--  This program is free software; you can redistribute it and/or modify    --
--  it under the terms of the GNU General Public License as published by    --
--  the Free Software Foundation; version 2 of the License.                 --
--                                                                          --
--  This program is distributed in the hope that it will be useful,         --
--  but WITHOUT ANY WARRANTY; without even the implied warranty of          --
--  MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.  See the           --
--  GNU General Public License for more details.                            --
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
import Expr
import Text.ParserCombinators.Parsec
import Text.ParserCombinators.Parsec.Expr
import Text.ParserCombinators.Parsec.Token
import Text.ParserCombinators.Parsec.Language (emptyDef)
import Text.ParserCombinators.Parsec.Pos
import Ratio (approxRational)

instance Read Expr where
  readsPrec _ = either (const []) id . parse lineExpr' ""
    where lineExpr' = do a <- lineExpr
                         rest <- getInput
                         return [(a, rest)]


lang :: TokenParser st
-- Language token parser: permits removing spaces (no newlines) easily
lang  = makeTokenParser emptyDef {commentLine = "#"}

lineExprRow :: Line -> GenParser Char st Expr
-- Parses an expression given a line number
lineExprRow n =  do p <- getPosition
                    setPosition (setSourceLine p n)
                    lineExpr 

lineExpr :: CharParser st Expr
-- Parses an expression from a line removing white spaces at the begining
lineExpr = do whiteSpace lang
              e <- expr
              eof 
              return e

expr :: CharParser st Expr
-- Expression parser
expr    = buildExpressionParser table factor
         <?> "expression"

table :: [[Operator Char st Expr]]
-- Table of operands, for some reason in Norvigs book the operands
-- are Right associative and "/" has a higher precedence than "*"
-- (same goes with "-" and "+")
table = [map (\str -> prefixfun str (Func str)) functions         -- functions
          ,[prefix "-" Negate, prefix "+" id]                  -- unary opers
          ,[op "^" (:^:) AssocRight]                         -- exponent
          ,[op "/" (:/:) AssocRight],[op "*" (:*:) AssocRight] -- / *
          ,[op "-" (:-:) AssocRight],[op "+" (:+:) AssocRight] -- - +
         ]
         where
           op s f assoc
              = Infix (do{ symbol lang s; return f} <?> "operator") assoc
           prefix s f = Prefix (do symbol lang s 
                                   return f
                                <?> "prefix op")
           -- Make sure the function symbols are followed by a separator
           prefixfun s f = Prefix (do try (string s >> followedBySep)
                                      whiteSpace lang
                                      return f
                                   <?> "function")
           consExp lhs rhs = lhs :^: rhs              


followedBySep :: GenParser Char st ()
-- Make sure a function name is followed by a space or opening parentesis)
followedBySep   = notFollowedBy (noneOf "( \v\f\t\r\n")

followedBySepOp :: GenParser Char st ()
-- Make sure a constant symbol is followed by a separator or operator,
-- closing parenthsis or eof
followedBySepOp = (notFollowedBy (noneOf ") \v\f\t\r\n+-/+^") <|> eof)
                  <?> "separator, operator or end of input"                  

functions :: [String]
-- List of valid function identifiers
functions = ["log","exp","sin","cos","tan","sinh","cosh","tanh"]

cSymbols :: [String]
-- List of valid constant symbols
cSymbols = ["e","pi"] 

parseCSymbols :: GenParser Char st Expr
-- parser of valid constant symbols
parseCSymbols = choice (map parseOne cSymbols) 
  where parseOne str = do string str
                          followedBySepOp                                      
                          whiteSpace lang
                          return (CSym str)
                       <?> "csymbol"


parseVar :: GenParser Char st Expr
parseVar = do {c <- lexeme lang letter; return (Var c)}


parseD :: GenParser Char st Expr
-- Parse a Derivative expression (D (cos x) x)
parseD = parseBinary "D" D 

parseI :: GenParser Char st Expr
-- Parse an Integral expression (for example "I (sin x) x")
parseI = parseBinary "I" I 

parseBinary :: String -> (Expr -> Char -> Expr) -> GenParser Char st Expr
-- Parse binary functions of the type "char expression variable"
-- Used for parsing derivatives (D expr var) and integrals (I expr var)
parseBinary s f = do string s
                     followedBySep
                     whiteSpace lang
                     e <- expr
                     -- FIXME: how to check a separator here?
                     --        (expr is a lexem parser, so it runs whiteSpace) 
                     c <- lexeme lang letter
                     return (f e c)
 

factor :: GenParser Char st Expr
-- Parser of a terms included in an expression
factor  =    -- an expression between parens
             parens lang expr
             -- a constant symbol
         <|> parseCSymbols
             -- an integral or a derivative
         <|> parseI <|> parseD
             -- a variable 
         <|> parseVar
             -- a number
         <|> do {e <- naturalOrFloat lang; return (either2const e)}
         <?> "subexpression"

either2const :: Either Integer Double -> Expr
-- transform an either expression into a constant
either2const (Left i)  = Const (fromInteger i)
-- we approximate the float number to a close rational 
-- to avoid things as 0.9 => 8106479329266893 % 9007199254740992
either2const (Right d) = Const (approxRational (realToFrac d) 0.000000001)

title: Expr.hs
contents:
module Expr (Expr (..), freeOf, freeOfList, isConst, 
             notConst, factorize, unfactorize, querep, (<**>)) 
where
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--               2D1456, Advanced Functional Programming                    --
--               Mini project: P1.2 Symbolic Integration                    --
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--               Author: Alfonso Acosta Gómez                               --
--               Date:   March-May 2006                                     --
--               e-mail: alfonso.acosta@gmail.com                           --
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-- Description: Toy symbolic integrator based on the Lisp code included in  -- 
--              Chapter 8 from:                                             --
--               Norvig, "Paradigms of Artificial Intelligence Programming: --
--               Case Studies in Common Lisp", Morgan Kaufmann              --
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-- Module: Expr.hs,Type and aux functions to represent symbolic expressions --
------------------------------------------------------------------------------

import Maybe
import Ratio

-- Expr: A type to internally represent symbolic expressions 
-- (using infix constructors)

-- I first tried to make Expresions polymorphic (i.e. data Num a =>
-- Exp a = ... | Const a | ...)  but due to the hard typing of Haskell
-- it leaded to so may problems (see the operator ^^, for example)
-- that I had to stick to Fractionals. The polymorfism wasn't then so
-- wide, and to simplify it (and avoid to type the polymorphic
-- parameter all the time), I decided to use Rationals
data Expr = 
              -- Variables and Constants
              Var Char | Const Rational | 
              -- Binary operators (using infix constructors)
              Expr :+: Expr  | Expr  :-: Expr  |
              Expr :*: Expr  | Expr  :/: Expr  |
              Expr :^: Expr |
              -- Unary operators
              Negate Expr |
              -- Functions
              -- e.g. sin(x) is internally represented as Func "sin" (Var 'x')
              Func String Expr |
              -- Integrals and Derivatives
              -- i.e: integral(x,x) => I (Var 'x') 'x'
              I Expr Char | D Expr Char |
              -- Constant symbols such as pi, e ...
              CSym String |
              -- Undefined valude
              Undefined

  deriving Eq

-- Operand associativity and precedence following Norvig's (strange) convention

-- I,D, and functions have precedence 10
--negate has precedence 9
infixr 8 :^:
infixr 7 :/:
infixr 6 :*:
infixr 5 :-:
infixr 4 :+:

showsPrecInfix :: (Show a1, Show a) =>
                  Int -> Int -> a -> [Char] -> a1 -> String -> String
-- function used for shosPrec with binary constructors
showsPrecInfix c d a op b = showParen (d>c) $
                            showsPrec (c+1) a . 
                            showString (" "++op++" ") .
                            showsPrec (c+1) b 


instance Show Expr where
-- Pretty print an expression
-- unfortunately showsPrec can't eliminate brackets due to associavity
-- a more sohpisticate prettyprint library would be required in order
-- to do that
 showsPrec d (Var x) = showChar x 
 showsPrec d (Const x) = shows (numerator x) . possibly (denominator x)
   where possibly 1 = showString ""
         possibly n = showString "/" . shows n  
 showsPrec d (a :+: b) = showsPrecInfix 4 d a "+" b   
 showsPrec d (a :-: b) = showsPrecInfix 5 d a "-" b   
 showsPrec d (a :*: b) = showsPrecInfix 6 d a "*" b
 showsPrec d (a :/: b)   = showsPrecInfix 7 d a "/" b
 showsPrec d (a :^: b)   = showsPrecInfix 8 d a "^" b
 showsPrec d (Negate a)  = showParen (d>9)$ 
                           showString "- " . showsPrec (10) a
 showsPrec d (Func str expr) = showParen (d>10)$
                               showString (str++" ") . showsPrec 11 expr
 showsPrec d (I expr x)  = showParen (d>10)$
                               showString "I " . showsPrec 11 expr. 
                               showString " ". showChar x
 showsPrec d (D expr x)  = showParen (d>10)$
                               showString "D " . showsPrec 11 expr. 
                               showString " ". showChar x
 showsPrec d (CSym str)  = showString str
 showsPrec d Undefined   = showString "undefined"




-- We can interestingly make Expr an instance of Num
-- (which is going to be useful later)
instance Num Expr where
 negate e = Negate e
 e1 - e2  = e1 :-: e2
 e1 + e2  = e1 :+: e2
 e1 * e2  = e1 :*: e2
 abs (Const a)  = Const (abs a)
 abs (Negate a) = a
 abs e          = Func "abs" e
 fromInteger i  = Const (fromInteger i)
 signum = (\_ -> error "Signum doesn't apply to expressions") 

---------------------
-- Auxiliar functions
---------------------

-- We can also create a fold operation for the expressions
-- but we need a different function for every non ending node
-- The fold expression might be too difficult then.
-- See as an example http://haskell.org/hawiki/WhatIsaFold

-- foldExpr :: 


freeOf :: Expr -> Char -> Bool
-- Tells if an expresions is free of certain variable
-- (designated by a char)
freeOf (Var x) y = x /= y
freeOf (Const _) y = True   
freeOf (CSym  _) y = True
freeOf Undefined _ = True
freeOf (l :+: r) y = freeOf l y && freeOf r y  
freeOf (l :-: r) y = freeOf l y && freeOf r y  
freeOf (l :*: r) y = freeOf l y && freeOf r y  
freeOf (l :/: r) y = freeOf l y && freeOf r y  
freeOf (l :^: r) y = freeOf l y && freeOf r y  
freeOf (Negate x) y = freeOf x y 
freeOf (Func _ x) y = freeOf x y
freeOf (I    x _) y = freeOf x y
freeOf (D    x _) y = freeOf x y

freeOfList :: [Expr] -> Char -> Bool
freeOfList el x = and ((map ((flip freeOf) x)) el) 




isConst :: Expr -> Bool
-- Tells if a expression is a constant
isConst (Const _) = True
isConst _         = False

notConst :: Expr -> Bool
notConst = not.isConst


factorize :: Expr -> [Expr]
-- Given an expression, it returns its list of factors,
-- Each of those factors will have the form (Exp a) :^: Const a
factorize exp 
   | mconst == 0 = 
     [Const 0 :^: Const 1]
   | mconst == 1 =  factors
   | otherwise = (Const mconst :^: Const 1) : factors
     where (factors, mconst, _) = fac exp ([], 1, 1) 




fac :: Expr -> ([Expr], Rational, Rational) -> ([Expr], Rational, Rational)
-- Auxiliar function to factorize
--  It takes an expresion and calculates its list of factors (without 
--  considering the multiplicative constant of the expresion)
--
--  It makes use of 3 accumulative parameters:
--    factors: List of the previously obtained factors
--    mconst:  The implicit multiplicative constant of the expression
--    exp:     The implicit numeric exponent of the expression
fac (Const c) (factors, mconst, exp)          = (factors, mconst*c<**>exp, exp)
fac (lhs :*: rhs) acum@(factors, mconst, exp) = fac rhs (flhs, mclhs, exp)
  where (flhs, mclhs, _) = fac lhs acum 
fac (lhs :/: rhs) acum@(factors, mconst, exp) = fac rhs (flhs, mclhs, -exp)
  where (flhs, mclhs, _) = fac lhs acum 
fac (Negate expr) (factors, mconst, exp) = fac expr (factors, -mconst, exp) 
fac (lhs :^: (Const n)) (factors, mconst, exp) = 
  fac lhs (factors, mconst, exp * n)
fac expr (factors, const, exp) = 
  if isJust factors' then (fromJust factors', const, exp)
                     else (expr :^: (Const exp):factors, const, exp)
   where factors' = querep factors 
                    (\(lhs :^: _ ) -> lhs == expr)
                    (\(lhs :^: (Const n)) -> lhs :^: (Const (n+exp))) 
 

querep :: [a] -> (a -> Bool) -> (a -> a) -> Maybe [a]
-- Query and replace (by using `f`) the first ocurrence of the list which 
--  fullfils predicate p
-- If no element fullfills p it would return Nothing
querep [] _ _     = Nothing
querep (x:xs) p f 
  | p x        = Just ((f x):xs)
  | otherwise  = x `maycons` querep xs p f 
  where maycons _ Nothing   = Nothing
        maycons x (Just xs) = Just (x:xs) 


unfactorize :: [Expr] -> Expr
-- Creates the original expression from the factor list
unfactorize [] = (Const 1.0)
unfactorize xs = foldl1 (:*:) xs 

(<**>) :: Rational -> Rational -> Rational
a <**> b 
 | (denominator b) == 1 =  a ^^ numerator(b)   
 | otherwise     = toRational ((fromRational a) ** (fromRational b))

title: generalized field accessor
contents:
(defun length<= (length list)
  (or (zerop length) (and list (length<= (1- length) (cdr list)))))

(defun -> (object &rest path)
  (cond
    ((null path) object)
    ((arrayp object)
     (let ((d (array-rank object)))
       (if (length<= d path)
           (apply (function ->)
                  (apply (function aref) object (subseq path 0 d))
                  (nthcdr d path))
           (make-array                  ; let's get a slice
            (nthcdr (length path) (array-dimensions object))
            :displaced-to object
            :displaced-index-offset
            (apply (function array-row-major-index) object
                   (append path (make-list (- d (length path))
                                           :initial-element 0)))
            :element-type (array-element-type object)))))
    ((and (listp object)
          (every (function consp) object)
          (not (integerp (first path))))
     (apply (function ->) (cdr (assoc (first path) object)) (rest path)))
    ((listp object)
     (apply (function ->) (elt object (first path)) (rest path)))
    ((hash-table-p object)
     (apply (function ->) (gethash (first path) object) (rest path)))
    ((typep object '(or structure-object standard-object))
     (apply (function ->) (funcall (first path) object) (rest path)))
    ((or (functionp (first path))
         (and (symbolp (first path)) (fboundp (first path))))
     (apply (function ->) (funcall (first path) object) (rest path)))
    (t (error "This is not a compound object: ~S" object))))

title: the function `fringe' does not work
contents:
Write a procedure fringe that takes as argument a tree (represented as a list) and returns a list whose elements are all the leaves of the tree arranged in left-to-right order. For example,

(define x (list (list 1 2) (list 3 4)))

(fringe x)
(1 2 3 4)

(fringe (list x x))
(1 2 3 4 1 2 3 4)

;; Program follows

(define (append list1 list2)
  (if (null? list1)
      list2
      (cons (car list1) (append (cdr list1) list2))))

(define (fringe lst)
  (cond ((null? lst) lst)
	((not (pair? lst)) (list lst))
	(append (fringe (car lst)) (fringe (cdr lst)))))

title: parsec token example
contents:
module Teste where

import Text.ParserCombinators.Parsec

-- We do this because we dont want to use integer as
-- defined in ParsecToken
import qualified Text.ParserCombinators.Parsec.Token as P
import Text.ParserCombinators.Parsec.Language

lexer   = P.makeTokenParser haskellDef
integer = P.integer lexer
main = case (parse integer "" "2222") of Right xs -> print xs

-- Try ":t P.integer" and ":t P.integer lexer" in GHCi

title: can someone explain this httpd log?
64 bit question
contents:
# On Darwin we can use 64-bit instructions with a longlong limb,
            # but the chip still in 32-bit mode.
            # In theory this can be used on any OS which knows how to save
            # 64-bit registers in a context switch.
            #
            # Note that we must use -mpowerpc64 with gcc, since the
            # longlong.h macros expect limb operands in a single 64-bit
            # register, not two 32-bit registers as would be given for a
            # long long without -mpowerpc64.  In theory we could detect and
            # accomodate both styles, but the proper 64-bit registers will
            # be fastest and are what we really want to use.
            #
            # One would think -mpowerpc64 would set the assembler in the right
            # mode to handle 64-bit instructions.  But for that, also
            # -force_cpusubtype_ALL is needed.

title: postprocess logical pathname translations
contents:
#+sbcl
(defun post-process-logical-pathname-translations (host)
  (flet ((pstring (x) (if (pathnamep x) (namestring x) (string x))))
    (setf (logical-pathname-translations host)
          (sort (remove-if
                 (lambda (p) (and (< 5 (length p))
                             (string= "*.*.*" p :start2 (- (length p) 5))))
                 (logical-pathname-translations host)
                 :key (function first))
                (lambda (a b) (< (length (pstring (second a)))
                            (length (pstring (second b)))))))))

#+cliso
(DEFUN POST-PROCESS-LOGICAL-PATHNAME-TRANSLATIONS (HOST)
  (FLET ((PSTRING (X) (IF (PATHNAMEP X) (NAMESTRING X) (STRING X))))
    (SETF (LOGICAL-PATHNAME-TRANSLATIONS HOST)
          (SORT (REMOVE-IF
                 (LAMBDA (P) (LET ((P (PSTRING P)))
                          (AND (< 5 (LENGTH P))
                               (STRING= "*.*.*" P :START2 (- (LENGTH P) 5)))))
                 (LOGICAL-PATHNAME-TRANSLATIONS HOST)
                 :KEY (FUNCTION FIRST))
                (LAMBDA (A B) (> (LENGTH (PSTRING (FIRST A)))
                            (LENGTH (PSTRING (FIRST B)))))))))

title: CAPT 'CHA
contents:
;;;;;;;;;;;;;;
;
;
;          CAPTured 'CHA
;          -------------
;          A Completely Automated Public Turing test
;            to tell Computers and Humans Apart
;            generator.
;
;          Generates simple written arithmatic problems.
;
;
;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

;;; Create Package CAPTCHA
(eval-when (:compile-toplevel)
  (require "ITERATE"))
(defpackage "CAPTCHA"
  (:use "CL"
	"ITERATE")
  (:export "GENERATE-CAPTCHA"))
(in-package "CAPTCHA")

#| Some possible captchas:

     "what is X times Y?"
     "if you have X As and give away Y how many remain?"
     "if you have X As and Y Bs how many things do you have?"
     
     "obtain X As and Y Bs, how many things do you have?"
     "split X As into Y equal groups, how many in each group?"
     "what is a X percent sales tax on Y dollars?"

|#

(defconstant +numbermax+ 10)

(defconstant +objects+ '("apple"
			 "banana"
			 "apricot"
			 "watch"
			 "card"))

(defun gennumber (max &optional (min 0))
  (+ (random (- max min)) min))

(defun genzero (&rest ignore)
  (declare (ignore ignore))
  (gennumber 1))

(defclass query ()
  ((text
    :initarg :text
    :initform (error "Query must have text.")
    :documentation "FORMAT string to convert to captcha query.")
   (string-types
    :initarg :string-types
    :initform (error "Query must have FORMAT args.")
    :documentation "Arguments of generator functions which will produce values for captcha.")
   ))

(defclass query+ (query) ())
(defclass query- (query) ())
(defclass query* (query) ())
(defclass query/ (query) ())

;; DATABASE AND SUCH
(defvar *query-strings* '((* "what is ~r times ~r?"
			   (gennumber gennumber))
			  (* "what is the product of ~r and ~r?"
			   (gennumber gennumber))
			  (* "what is the area of a ~r by ~r rectangle?"
			   (gennumber gennumber))
			  (* "If you have ~r cards in a deck, then give the deck away, how many cards do you have?~*"
			   (gennumber genzero))
			  (+ "what is ~r plus ~r?"
			   (gennumber gennumber))
			  (+ "what is the sum of ~r, ~r, and ~r?"
			   (gennumber gennumber gennumber))
			  (+ "if you have ~r apricots and buy ~r more, how many do you have?"
			   (gennumber gennumber))
			  (- "what is ~r less ~r?"
			   (gennumber gennumber))
			  (- "what is the difference between ~r and ~r?"
			   (gennumber gennumber))
			  (- "if you have ~r dollars but owe ~r, you effectively have how many?"
			   (gennumber gennumber))
			  (/ "what is ~r over ~r?"
			   (gennumber gennumber))
			  (/ "what is the quotient of ~r and ~r"
			   (gennumber gennumber))
			  (/ "if you split ~r watches into ~r equal groups, how many are in each group?"
			   (gennumber gennumber))))
; Etc...


(defun generate-query-database (&optional (data *query-strings*))
  (iter
    (for query in data)
    (collecting (let ((type   (first query))
		      (string (second query))
		      (args   (third query)))
		  (make-instance (intern (concatenate 'string
						      "QUERY"
						      (symbol-name type)))
				 :text string
				 :string-types args)))))


(defvar *db* (generate-query-database))

;; PERFORM QUERY
;
;  Returns a string to print and a string to be compared against as the answer. 
(defgeneric perform (q &optional string-args))

(defmacro perform-values (q fn string-args)
  (let ((s-a string-args))
    `(values (apply #'format (append (list nil (slot-value ,q 'text))
			      ,s-a))
             (format nil "~a" (reduce ,fn (remove-if #'stringp ,s-a)))
             ,s-a)))

(defmethod perform :around ((q query) &optional string-args)
  (call-next-method q (or string-args
			  (mapcar (lambda (x)
				    (funcall x +numbermax+))
				  (slot-value q 'string-types)))))

(defmethod perform ((q query/) &optional (string-args ()))
			 ; Avoid division by 0.
  (perform-values q #'/ (substitute-if (gennumber +numbermax+ 1) #'zerop  string-args)))

(defmethod perform ((q query*) &optional (string-args ()))
  (perform-values q #'* string-args))

(defmethod perform ((q query+) &optional (string-args ()))
  (perform-values q #'+ string-args))

(defmethod perform ((q query-) &optional (string-args ()))
  (perform-values q #'- (sort (copy-list string-args) #'>)))

;; GENERATE-CAPTCHA
(defun generate-captcha (&key type (db *db*))
  "Produces a random CAPTCHA from DB. If TYPE is supplied, only CAPTCHAs of that
   type may be returned."
  (let ((db (remove-if (if type
			   (lambda (x)
			     (not (eq (type-of x) type)))
			   (constantly nil))
		       db)))
    (perform (elt db (random (length db))))))

title: erlang ring demo...
contents:
-module(ring).
-export([start/2, doit/2]).

% Entry point... creates the first process that creates the others in
% doit, also sends the first message with it's own PID to the immediate
% ring neighbor
start(N,M) ->
	Pid = spawn(ring, doit, [N-1, M]),
	Pid ! {self()},
	worker(Pid, M).

% This is the last process to be spawned... it calls "worker/1"
doit(0,M) -> 
	worker(M);

% All of the middle ranks in the ring run the following algorithm
doit(N,M) ->
	Neighbor = spawn(ring, doit, [N-1, M]),
	worker(Neighbor, M).

% This version of worker is for that last rank and the last message
worker(0) ->
	receive
		{Pid} ->
			io:format("Message 0~n", []),
			Pid ! {Pid}
	end;
% The last rank for all but the last message
worker(M) ->
	receive
		{Pid} -> 
			io:format("Message ~w~n", [M]),
			Pid ! {Pid}
	end,
	worker(M-1).

% All but the last message for the middle ranks
worker(Neighbor, 0) ->
	receive
		{Pid} -> 
			Neighbor ! {Pid}
	end;

% worker algorithm for all the middle ranks for all but the last message
worker(Neighbor, M) -> 
	receive
		{Pid} -> 
			Neighbor ! {Pid}
	end,
	worker(Neighbor, M-1).

title: assignment 6.22 from Haskell:The Craft of Functional Programming

I am supposed to use
6.21

>       formatLine :: (Name, Price) -> String
>       formatLine (n,p)
>          | length n == lineLength     = n ++ formatPence p ++ "\n"
>          | otherwise                  = formatLine (n ++ ".", p)

this code for this function

formatLines :: [ (Name, Price) ] -> String
which applies each (Name, Price) pair and joins the results.

Here are two attempts. I am thouroughly confused at this point. But what I would like to do is a recursive solution.
All I need is the right track. I think I'm way off and not understanding something important about how haskell works.
Here are my two attempts

6.22

        formatLines :: [ (Name, Price)] -> String
        formatLines []  = []
        formatLines [ (n,p) ] =
          formattedLines
           where
           formattedLines =
             formatLine (head [ (n,p) ]) ++ formatLines (tail [ (n,p) ])

>       formatLines :: [ (Name, Price)] -> String
>       formatLines  [(name,price)]
>          = [ [(n,p)] | (n,p) <- formatLine (unzip (concat([(name,price)]))]

title: Parser for JavaScript Object Notation
contents:
;;; parser for json syntax (http://json.org/)
;;; numbers are not yet handled
;;;
;;; tested with sisc (http://sisc.sf.net/)
;;;
;;; (c) Jörn Horstmann (http://blog.planetxml.de/)
(module json
  (json/tokenize json/tokenize-string json/parse json/parse-string)

  (import string-io)

  (define (json/parse p)
    (with-input-from-port p parse-object))

  (define (json/parse-string str)
    (with-input-from-string str parse-object))

  (define (json/tokenize p)
    (with-input-from-port p tokenize))

  (define (json/tokenize-string str)
    (with-input-from-string str tokenize))

  (define (tokenize)
    (let loop ((res '())
               (token (next-token)))
      (if (eof-object? token)
          (reverse res)
          (loop (cons token res) (next-token)))))

  ;;; helper for error reporting
  (define (->string x)
    (cond
      ((char? x) (string x))
      ((symbol? x) (symbol->string x))
      ((eof-object? x) "<EOF>")
      (else "")))

  ;;; testing for control characters, handles only ascii and iso-8859-1 characters
  (define (char-control? ch)
    (let ((i (char->integer ch)))
      (or (< i 32)
          (< 127 i 160))))

  (define (lexer-error ch)
    (error (string-append "unexpected character " (->string ch))))

  (define (parse-error token)
    (error (string-append "unexpected token " (->string token))))

  ;;; reads a character and signals an error if it does not match the expected character
  (define (consume-char expect)
    (let ((ch (read-char)))
      (if (eqv? ch expect)
          ch
          (lexer-error ch))))

  (define (next-token)
    (let ((ch (read-char)))
      (case ch
        ((#\space #\newline #\tab #\return) (next-token))
        ((#\[) 'open-brace)
        ((#\]) 'close-brace)
        ((#\{) 'open-curly)
        ((#\}) 'close-curly)
        ((#\:) 'colon)
        ((#\,) 'comma)
        ((#\" #\') (parse-string ch))
        ((#\t) (parse-true))
        ((#\f) (parse-false))
        ((#\n) (parse-null))
        (else (if (eof-object? ch)
                  ch
                  (lexer-error ch))))))

  ;;; reads the symbol 'true, the first character is already read by next-token
  (define (parse-true)
    (begin
      (consume-char #\r)
      (consume-char #\u)
      (consume-char #\e)
      #t))

  ;;; reads the symbol 'false the first character is already read by next-token
  (define (parse-false)
    (begin
      (consume-char #\a)
      (consume-char #\l)
      (consume-char #\s)
      (consume-char #\e)
      #f))

  ;;; reads the symbol 'null the first character is already read by next-token
  (define (parse-null)
    (begin
      (consume-char #\u)
      (consume-char #\l)
      (consume-char #\l)
      '()))

  (define (parse-string q)
    (let loop ((res ""))
      (let ((ch (read-char)))
        (cond
          ((eqv? ch #\\) (loop (string-append res (string (parse-escape q)))))
          ((eqv? ch q) res)
          ((eqv? ch q) res)
          ((not (char-control? ch)) (loop (string-append res (string ch))))
          (else (lexer-error ch))))))

  (define (parse-escape q)
    (let ((ch (read-char)))
      (case ch
        ((#\b) #\backspace)
        ((#\f) #\page)
        ((#\n) #\newline)
        ((#\r) #\return)
        ((#\t) #\tab)
        ((#\\) #\\)
        ((#\u) (parse-unicode))
        (else (if (eqv? ch q)
                  q
                  (lexer-error ch))))))

  (define (numeric-char-value ch)
    (- (char->integer ch) (char->integer #\0)))

  (define (hex-char-value ch)
    (let ((i (char->integer ch)))
      (cond ((<= 97 i 102) (- i 87)) ; a-f
            ((<= 65 i 70)  (- i 55)) ; A-F
            ((<= 48 i 57)  (- i 48)) ; 0-9
            (else (lexer-error ch)))))

  ;;; parse an unicode escape consisting of four hexadecimal characters
  (define (parse-unicode)
    (let* ((a (hex-char-value (read-char)))
           (b (hex-char-value (read-char)))
           (c (hex-char-value (read-char)))
           (d (hex-char-value (read-char))))
      (integer->char (+ (* 4096 a)
                        (*  256 b)
                        (*   16 c)
                        d))))

  (define (parse-object)
    (parse-object-helper (next-token)))

  (define (parse-object-helper token)
    (cond
      ((eqv? token 'open-curly) (parse-map))
      ((eqv? token 'open-brace) (parse-list))
      ((null? token) token)
      ((string? token) token)
      ((number? token) token)
      ((boolean? token) token)
      (else (parse-error token))))

  (define (parse-map)
    (let loop ((res '(map)))
      (let ((token (next-token)))
        (cond
          ((eqv? token 'close-curly) (reverse res))
          ((string? token) (let* ((res (cons (list (string->symbol token) (parse-map-value))
                                             res))
                                  (next (next-token)))
                             (cond
                               ((eqv? next 'close-curly) (reverse res))
                               ((eqv? next 'comma) (loop res))
                               (else (parse-error next)))))
          (else (parse-error token))))))

  (define (parse-map-value)
    (let ((token (next-token)))
        (if (eqv? token 'colon)
            (parse-object)
            (parse-error token))))

  (define (parse-list)
    (let loop ((res '(list)))
      (let ((token (next-token)))
        (cond
          ((eqv? token 'close-brace) (reverse res))
          (else (let* ((res (cons (list 'item (parse-object-helper token)) res))
                       (next (next-token)))
                  (cond
                    ((eqv? next 'close-brace) (reverse res))
                    ((eqv? next 'comma) (loop res))
                    (else (parse-error next)))))))))

  )

;; test
(import json)

(require-library 'webit/keyword)
(require-library 'webit/xml-core)
(import webit/keyword)
(import webit/xml-core)

(display (json/parse-string "{'a': ['a', 'b', 'c']}"))
(display #\newline)
(display (json/parse-string "{'abc': ['a', 'b', 'c'], 'xyz' :['a', 'b', 'c']}"))
(display #\newline)
(display (json/parse-string "{'abc': ['a', 'b', 'c']  , 'xyz' : [ 'abc']  }"))
(display #\newline)
(display (json/parse-string "{'abc': ['a', 'b', 'c']  , 'xyz' : [ false, true, null, 'abc']  }"))
(display #\newline)
(display (json/parse-string "{'abc': ['a', 'b', 'c']  , 'xyz' : ['123', '456', '789']  }"))
(display #\newline)
(display (json/parse-string "{'abc': [[[['abc']]]]}"))
(display #\newline)
(display-xml (json/parse-string "{'abc': ['a', 'b', 'c']  , 'xyz' : ['123', '456', '789']  }"))
(display #\newline)
(json/tokenize-string "{'abc': ['a', 'b', 'c',  { 'zasdf' : ['1', '2', '3']}]  , 'xyz' : ['123', '456', '789']  }")

(display-xml (json/parse-string "{'abc': ['a', 'b', 'c',  { 'zasf' : ['1', '2', '3']}]  , 'xyz' : ['123', '456', '789']  }"))
(display #\newline)

title: incorrect GUARD
contents:
(define-syntax guard
  (syntax-rules (ELSE)
    ((GUARD (var
             (condition then0 then1 ...)
             ...
             (ELSE else0 else1 ...))
       body0 body1 ...)
     (WITH-EXCEPTION-HANDLER (LAMBDA (var)
                               (COND (condition then0 then1 ...)
                                     (ELSE else0 else1 ...)))
       (LAMBDA () body0 body1 ...)))
    ((GUARD (var
             (condition then0 then1 ...)
             ...)
       body0 body1 ...)
     (GUARD (var
             (condition then0 then1 ...)
             (ELSE (RAISE var)))
       body0 body1 ...))))

title: test
contents:
Lock := 0; // Lock is available
  Res := InterLockedCompareExchange(Lock, 1, 0); // Res=0 Lock=1 -> meaning Lock acquired successfully
  Res := InterLockedCompareExchange(Lock, 1, 0); // Another thread trying to acquire the lock will have Res=1 since Lock=1 -> meaning unsuccessfull Lock already acquired
  Lock := 0; // Releasing the Lock
  Res := InterLockedCompareExchange(Lock, 1, 0); // Res=0 Lock=1 -> meaning Lock acquired successfully
  Res := InterLockedCompareExchange(Lock, 1, 0); // Another thread trying to acquire the lock will have Res=1 since Lock=1 -> meaning unsuccessfull Lock already acquired
