contents:
; Why is this giving this error with GNU CLISP?
; I hope you don't mind it looking so much like crap
;
; It's supposed to pull a piece out of a string and cons add it to the *keys-to-spider* list.
;
; WARNING: locale: no encoding , using UTF-8
; WARNING: *FOREIGN-ENCODING*: reset to ASCII
;
; *** - SYSTEM::%EXPAND-FORM:
; (CONS *KEYS-TO-SPIDER*
;  (LAMBDA NIL
;   (MODIFY-USK-TO-NEGATIVE-TYPE
;    (LAMBDA (LINE)
;     (SUBSEQ LINE (LAMBDA NIL (LAMBDA NIL (+ (LAMBDA (LINE) (SEARCH "<a href=\"USK@" LINE)) 10)))
;      (LAMBDA (LINE) (SEARCH "/>" LINE))))))) should be a lambda expression

(setf *keys-to-spider* nil)
(setf *spidered-keys* nil)

(DEFUN modify-usk-to-negative-type (line)
  (line))

(DEFUN parse-line-for-keys (line)
  ((cons *keys-to-spider*
         (lambda ()
           (modify-usk-to-negative-type
            (lambda (line)
              (subseq line
                      (lambda ()
                        (lambda ()
                          (+ (lambda (line)
                               (search "<a href=\"USK@"
                                       line))
                             10)))
                      (lambda (line)
                        (search "/>"
                                line)))))))
   (cons *keys-to-spider* (subseq line
                                  (+ (search "<a href=\"SSK@" line)
                                     10)
                                  (search "/>" line)))
   (cons *keys-to-spider* (subseq line
                                  (+ (search "<a href=\"CHK@" line)
                                     10)
                                  (search "/>" line)))
   (cons *keys-to-spider* (subseq line
                                  (+ (search "<a href=\"KSK@" line)
                                     10)
                                  (search "/>" line)))
   (*keys-to-spider* = (remove-dumplicates *keys-to-spider*))
   (*spidered-keys* = (remove-duplicates *spidered-keys*))
   (LOOP :for key = (car *keys-to-spider*) :while (not (eq? key nil))
         .do (*keys-to-spider* = (remove-if (search key
                                                    *spidered-keys*)
                                            *keys-to-spider*)))))

title: merge
contents:
(define (merge a b) 
  (cond ((null? a) 
         b) 
        ((null? b) 
         a) 
        ((= (car a) (car b)) 
         (cons (car a) (merge (cdr a) (cdr b)))) 
        ((< (car a) (car b)) 
         (cons (car a) (merge (cdr a) b))) 
        ((< (car b) (car a)) 
         (cons (car b) (merge a (cdr b))))))

title: hopefully portable commit.sh script for sbcl
contents:
#!/bin/sh -e

## commit to the SBCL repository, with error checks.
## Written in 2006 by Andreas Fuchs <asf@boinkor.net>

set -e

cd `dirname $0`

# Check that the committer has a chance of succeeding

if grep -l '^:pserver:anonymous@' CVS/Root 2>/dev/null >/dev/null ; then
    echo "You must execute this script in a tree checked out from developer CVS." >&2
    echo "See http://sourceforge.net/cvs/?group_id=1373 for details." >&2
    exit 1
fi

echo -n "CVS status running..." >&2

if cvs status -R . 2>/dev/null | grep -l "Status: Needs Patch" >/dev/null ; then
    echo "This tree is not up to date." >&2
    echo "Please run cvs up and try again." >&2
    exit 1
fi

echo "done">&2

# Check that the version is correct

OLDVERSION=$(eval echo $(cvs up -p version.lisp-expr 2>/dev/null | tail -n 1))
OLDVERSION_="$OLDVERSION".
NEWVERSION=$(eval echo $(tail -n 1 version.lisp-expr))
NEWVERSION_="$NEWVERSION".

if [ "$NEWVERSION" = "$OLDVERSION" ]; then
    echo "The new version must be greater than the version of the\
 latest commit in the repository (currently $OLDVERSION). Please edit\
 version.lisp-expr and try again." | fmt >&2
    exit 1
fi

while [ x"$NEWVERSION_" != x ] && [ x"$OLDVERSION_" != x ] ; do
    newcomp="`echo $NEWVERSION_ | cut -f 1 -d .`"
    NEWVERSION_="`echo $NEWVERSION_ | cut -f 2- -d .`"
    oldcomp="`echo $OLDVERSION_ | cut -f 1 -d .`"
    OLDVERSION_="`echo $OLDVERSION_ | cut -f 2- -d .`"

    # can't use integer comparison via -lt. so we use sort.
    correctorder=$( (echo "$oldcomp"; echo "$newcomp") | sort -n | (
            read lesser ; read greater;
            if [ "$greater" = "$newcomp" ] && [ "$lesser" = "$oldcomp" ] ; then
                echo "yes"
            else
                echo "no"
            fi
        ) )
    if [ "$correctorder" = "no" ]; then
        echo "The new version must be greater than the version of the\
 latest commit in the repository (currently $OLDVERSION). Please edit\
 version.lisp-expr and try again." | fmt >&2
        exit 1
    fi
done

# Get the commit message

MSGFILE="/tmp/sbcl-commit-msg.$$"
trap "rm '$MSGFILE'" EXIT
printf "$NEWVERSION:\n\t" >"$MSGFILE"
"$EDITOR" "$MSGFILE"
if [ "$(head -1 "$MSGFILE")" = "$NEWVERSION:" ] ; then :
else
    echo "First line of commit message must include the version number."
    exit 1
fi

if [ "`cat "$MSGFILE"`" = "`printf "$NEWVERSION:\n\t"`" ] ; then
    echo "No commit message specified. Exiting."
    exit 0
fi

# first version.lisp-expr
cvs commit -F "$MSGFILE" -l .
# Now the rest of the changes.
cvs commit -F "$MSGFILE" .

title: Worst EXPT ever
contents:
;; Constraint: the use of multiplication
;; and the built-in EXPT are forbidden.

(define (expt-hack x y)
  (let ((yabs (abs y))
        (mult (lambda (v1 v2)
                (apply + (vector->list (make-vector v1 v2))))))
    (cond ((or (not (integer? x))
               (not (integer? y)))
           #f)
          ((= y 0) 1)
          ((< y 0)
           (/ 1 (mult x (expt-hack x (- yabs 1)))))
          (else
           (mult x (expt-hack x (- yabs 1)))))))

;; I really don't want my name associated with this bile.

### The authz-db option controls the location of the authorization
### rules for path-based access control.  Unless you specify a path
### starting with a /, the file's location is relative to the conf
### directory.  If you don't specify an authz-db, no path-based access
### control is done.
### Uncomment the line below to use the default authorization file.
authz-db = authz
### This option specifies the authentication realm of the repository.
### If two repositories have the same authentication realm, they should
### have the same password database, and vice versa.  The default realm
### is repository's uuid.
# realm = My First Repository

title: NSString
casi
contents:
(defvar xgp-casi-left-PAREN-old nil
  "Command used to input \"(\"")
(make-variable-buffer-local 'xgp-casi-left-PAREN-old)

(defvar xgp-casi-DEL-old nil
  "Command used to delete a character")
(make-variable-buffer-local 'xgp-casi-DEL-old)

(defmacro xgp-casi-gnu-enter (var key cmd)
  "When switching to GNU style, save command for keystroke KEY into VAR and set command for it as CMD.
If the previous style is GNU as well, do nothing."
  `(if (equal ,var nil)
       (progn (setq ,var (lookup-key (current-local-map) ,key))
	      (local-set-key ,key ,cmd))))

(defmacro xgp-casi-nongnu-enter (var key)
  "When switching from GNU style to another, restore backuped command VAR for keystroke KEY."
  `(if ,var
       (progn (local-set-key ,key ,var)
	      (setq ,var nil))))

(defun xgp-casi-modify-alist (alist term new)
  (let ((tl (assq term (symbol-value alist))))
    (if tl
	(setcdr tl new)
      (add-to-list alist (cons term new)))))

;; C/C++ Automatic Style Inputing
(defun xgp-casi (style)
  "Deciding whether using CASI."
  (interactive "sStyle: ")

  (if (equal style "bsd")

      (progn  (c-set-style "bsd")
	      (setq indent-tabs-mode t
		    c-hanging-braces-alist (quote ((defun-open after) (defun-close after) (brace-list-open after) (brace-list-close) (brace-entry-open after) (statement-cont after) (substatement-open after) (block-close . c-snug-do-while) (extern-lang-open after) (namespace-open after) (module-open after) (composition-open after) (inexpr-class-open after) (inexpr-class-close after) (class-open after) (class-close)))
		    c-hanging-colons-alist (quote ((label after) (case-label after) (access-label after)))
		    c-hanging-semi&comma-criteria (quote (c-semi&comma-inside-parenlist)))
	      (local-set-key " " 'xgp-casi-bsd-SPC))

    (progn  (c-set-style style)
	    (setq indent-tabs-mode nil
		  c-hanging-colons-alist (quote ((label after) (case-label after) (access-label after)))
		  c-hanging-semi&comma-criteria (quote (c-semi&comma-inside-parenlist)))

	    ;; CLASS-CLOSE
	    (xgp-casi-modify-alist 'c-hanging-braces-alist 'class-close nil)
	    (xgp-casi-modify-alist 'c-hanging-braces-alist 'brace-list-close nil)
	    (local-set-key " " 'self-insert-command)

	    (if (equal style "gnu")
		(progn
		  ;; GNU style needs a ' ' before '('
		  (xgp-casi-gnu-enter xgp-casi-left-PAREN-old "(" 'xgp-casi-gnu-left-PAREN)
		  ;; the ' ' before '(' in most conditions should be deleted automatically
		  (xgp-casi-gnu-enter xgp-casi-DEL-old (kbd "DEL") 'xgp-casi-gnu-DEL)))))

  ;; restore old command as need
  (if (not (equal style "gnu"))
      (progn
	(xgp-casi-nongnu-enter xgp-casi-left-PAREN-old "(")
	(xgp-casi-nongnu-enter xgp-casi-DEL-old (kbd "DEL")))))

(defun xgp-casi-bsd-SPC ()
  (interactive)
  (if (looking-back "^[ \t]*}[ \t]*\n[ \t]*$")
      (let ((s (save-excursion (search-backward "}")
			       (1+ (point)))))
	(delete-region s (point))
	(insert " "))
    (insert " ")))

(defun xgp-casi-gnu-left-PAREN ()
  (interactive)
  (if (not (or (looking-back " ") (looking-back "(")))
      (insert " "))
  (funcall xgp-casi-left-PAREN-old nil))

(defun xgp-casi-gnu-DEL ()
  (interactive)
  (let ((c (char-before)))
    (funcall xgp-casi-DEL-old nil)
    (if (and (equal c ?\()
	     (not (or (looking-back "\\b\\(if\\|while\\|for\\|try\\|catch\\)[ \t]+")
		      (looking-back "("))))
	(funcall xgp-casi-DEL-old nil))))

(defun xgp-casi-erase-blanks ()
  "Erase all trivial blanks for CASI."
  (interactive)
  (save-excursion
    (goto-char (point-min))
    (while (re-search-forward "[ \t]+$" nil t)
      (replace-match "" nil nil))))

(defun xgp-casi2-space ()  
  "Inserting a space.
In BSD style, if inputing is after closing a brace list, move point back to previous line."
  (interactive)
  (let ((old-spc-cmd (xgp-casi2-old-key-binding (kbd "SPC"))))
    (cond ((string= xgp-casi2-style "bsd")
	   (if (looking-back "^[ \t]*}[ \t]*\n[ \t]*$")
	       (let ((s save-excursion (search-backward "}")
			(1+ (point))))
		 (delete-region s (point))
		 (funcall old-spc-cmd ?\ ))
	     (funcall old-spc-cmd ?\ )))
	  (t (funcall old-spc-cmd ?\ )))))

title: Skin class
contents:
data Scene a = Triangle (Vector a) (Vector a) (Vector a)
	| Rotated a (Vector a) (Scene a)
	| Translated (Vector a) (Scene a)
	| Scaled (Vector a) (Scene a)
	
data Key = UpArrow
	| DownArrow
	| LeftArrow
	| RightArrow

data KeyTransition = Down
	| Up

data Message = Keyboard Key KeyTransition

class Skin a where
	composite :: a -> obj -> state -> Scene b
	update :: a -> obj -> Message -> state -> state
	
data (Skin s) => ArrowKeyRotator s = ArrowKeyRotator s

data Num angle => AKRState angle childstate = AKRState angle childstate

instance Skin (ArrowKeyRotator subSkin) where
	composite (ArrowKeyRotator skin) obj (AKRState angle childstate) = Rotated angle (Vector3 1 0 0) (composite skin obj childstate)

title: NETWORK-TESTS error
unhelpful SBCL error message
contents:
I think that the error message emitted by SBCL as a reaction to entering
the following CFFI callback is a bit too obscure:

the callback:
(defcallback cb
    :pointer ((u :pointer) (avatar :uint32) (address :string) (host-id :pointer))
    (values nil))

the message:
debugger invoked on a SIMPLE-ERROR in thread
#<THREAD "initial thread" {A7BE489}>:
  Error during processing of --eval option "(load \"tests/cb\")":

  The value NIL is not of type SB-SYS:SYSTEM-AREA-POINTER.

In fact, even walking the debug stack is not much more suggestive of the cause.

title: CFFI return value requirement
contents:
(defcallback cb
    :pointer ((u :pointer) (avatar :uint32) (address :string) (host-id :pointer))
    (values nil))

vs.

(defcallback cb
    :pointer ((u :pointer) (avatar :uint32) (address :string) (host-id :pointer))
    (values (null-pointer)))

The latter works, the former produces on SBCL during the
callback invocation:

debugger invoked on a SIMPLE-ERROR in thread
#<THREAD "initial thread" {A7BE489}>:
  Error during processing of --eval option "(load \"tests/cb\")":

  The value NIL is not of type SB-SYS:SYSTEM-AREA-POINTER.

title: sudoku solver
contents:
;; sudoku.lisp
;;
;; Implements a sudoku solver. To use, just set the known elements of the
;; sudoku board (by using "(setf (cell i j) n)" repeatedly) and run "(solve)"
;; to get a solution. SOLVE returns T if a solution is found, and NIL
;; otherwise.

(defvar *board* (make-array '(9 9) :initial-element 0))

(defun print-board ()
  (print *board*))      ;; FIXME

(defun set-cell (i j n)
  (setf (aref *board* i j) n))

(defun cell (i j)
  (aref *board* i j))

(defsetf cell set-cell)

(defun invalid-p (x y n)
  (block leave
         ;; check all of the cells in the same row...
         (loop for j from 0 below 9 do
               (when (= (cell x j) n)
                 (return-from leave t)))
         ;; and the same column...
         (loop for i from 0 below 9 do
               (when (= (cell i y) n)
                 (return-from leave t)))
         ;; and the same 3-by-3 block.
         (let ((block-x (* (truncate x 3) 3))
               (block-y (* (truncate y 3) 3)))
           (loop for i from block-x below (+ block-x 3) do
                 (loop for j from block-y below (+ block-y 3) do
                       (when (= (cell i j) n)
                         (return-from leave t)))))
         nil))

(defun reset-board ()
  (setf *board* (make-array '(9 9) :initial-element 0)))

(defun next-cell (i j)
  (if (= i 8)
    (if (= j 8)
      nil
      (values 0 (1+ j)))
    (values (1+ i) j)))

(defun do-cell (i j)
  (if (= (cell i j) 0)
    (block exit
           ;; run through all the choices (1 to 9)
           (loop for n from 1 to 9 do
                 (when (not (invalid-p i j n))
                   ;; tenuously set the cell
                   (setf (cell i j) n)
                   ;; proceed recursively
                   (multiple-value-bind (ni nj) (next-cell i j)
                     (when (null ni)  ;; done here
                       (return-from exit t))
                     (when (do-cell ni nj)
                       (return-from exit t)))
                   ;; unsuccessful... undo and go on
                   (setf (cell i j) 0)))
           nil)
    ;; else
    (multiple-value-bind (ni nj) (next-cell i j)
      (if (null ni)
        t   ;; done here
        (do-cell ni nj)))))

(defun solve ()
  (do-cell 0 0))

title: basic interpreter
contents:
(defparameter *expr-hash-table* (make-hash-table :test #'eql))

(defmacro install-tag-handler ((tag &rest args) &rest action)
  `(setf (gethash ',tag *expr-hash-table*)
         #'(lambda (,@args) ,@action)))

(defun evaluate (form)
  (if (atom form)
    form
    (destructuring-bind (tag args) form
      (let ((func (get-hash tag *expr-hash-table*)))
        (apply func args)))))

(install-tag-handler (+ a b) (+ (evaluate a) (evaluate b)))
(install-tag-handler (* a b) (* (evaluate a) (evaluate b)))

title: neilv's email
contents:
This seems like a useful feature, and I recall wondering myself why
RnRS "cond" had "=>" yet "case" did not.

I suspect the distinction involved reduced-sugar diet: getting the value
of a clause test within "cond" is very hard without "=>", but getting
the key of a "case" form without "=>" is easy.

Also, "cond"'s "=>" is a somewhat unfortunate kind of sugar, as some
syntax transformers that can produce "cond" forms have to specially
handle "=>" identifiers in their input syntax.  Adding "=>" sugar to
"case" would similarly burden some syntax extensions that produce "case"
forms.

I'd like to be informed by the original wisdom for why "case" didn't
have a "=>" in the first place.  Does anyone know the RnRS rationale?

title: gmpc
contents:
# Description: gnome client for mpd (music player daemon)
# URL:         http://www.musicpd.org/?page=gmpc
# Maintainer:  Han Boetes <han@mijncomputer.nl>
# Packager:    Andrew Brouwers <abrouwers@gmail.com>
# Depends on:  gnome-vfs mpd libglade p5-xml-parser libmpd

name=gmpc
version=0.13.0
release=1
source=(http://download.qballcow.nl/programs/gmpc-0.13/$name-$version.tar.gz)

build()
{
    cd $name-$version
    ./configure \
        --prefix=/usr \
        --disable-nls
    make
    make install DESTDIR=$PKG
    rm -rf $PKG/usr/share/locale/
}

title: wtf
contents:
(defun expand-parse (name l &optional str pos)
  (cond
   ((null l) (list name str pos))
   ((equal 'p (car l)) (expand-parse name (cdr l) str (cons (length str) pos)))
   (t (expand-parse name (cdr l) (concat str (car l)) pos))))

(defun blah (l)
  (expand-parse (car l) (car (cdr l))))

(blah '("shebang" ("#!/usr/local/bin/ruby) -w\n\n"))) ; good

(blah '("tst" ("class Test" p " < Test::Unit::TestCase\n  def setup\n    " p "\n  end\n\n  def test_" p "\n    " p "\n  end\nend"))) ; throws because stack too deep - wtf

title: trouble with id
contents:
module OwlAst
    where

import List

type AnnotationPropertyID = String
type ClassID = String
type DataLiteral = String
type DatatypeID = String
type DatavaluedPropertyID = String
type IndividualID = String
type IndividualvaluedPropertyID = String
type OntologyPropertyID = String
type OntologyID = String
type URIreference = String


data Ontology = Ontology [directive]

data Directive 
  = Ontology_annotation { id :: OntologyPropertyID, ontology :: OntologyID }
  | Annotation Annotation
  | Fact Fact
  | Axiom Axiom

data Annotation
  = Ann_of_URI_reference
    { ann_prop_id :: AnnotationPropertyID, value :: URIreference }
  | Ann_of_data_literal
    { ann_prop_id :: AnnotationPropertyID,
      value :: DataLiteral }
  | Ann_of_individual
    { ann_prop_id :: AnnotationPropertyID,
      value :: Individual }

data Fact
  = An_individual Individual
  | Same_individual [IndividualID]
  | Different_individuals [IndividualID]

data Individual
  = Individual
    { id :: Mabey IndividualID,
      annotations :: [annotation],
      types :: [description],
      values :: [value] }

title: readtime-conditionals: all that I could think of off the top of my head.
contents:
(cl:defpackage #:readtime-conditionals
  (:nicknames #:rc)
  (:use #:cl)
  (:export #:read-if #:read-if-symbol-in-package #:read-if-fbound #:read-if-bound))

(cl:in-package #:readtime-conditionals)

(defun exportedp (name package)
  (let ((foundp nil))
    (do-external-symbols (sym package foundp)
      (setf foundp (or foundp (string= name sym))))))

(defun read-if (condition)
  (if condition
      '(:and)
      '(:or)))

(defun read-if-symbol-in-package (name package &key (exportedp nil) (test #'identity))
  (read-if (and (find-package package)
                (find-symbol name package)
                (funcall test (find-symbol name package))
                (or (not exportedp)
                    (exportedp name package)))))

(defun read-if-fbound (name package &key (exportedp nil))
  (read-if-symbol-in-package name package :exportedp exportedp :test #'fboundp))


(defun read-if-bound (name package &key (exportedp nil))
  (read-if-symbol-in-package name package :exportedp exportedp :test #'boundp))

title: non working code
contents:
tell application "Finder"
	set sels to selection
end tell

repeat with sel in sels
	set this_file to sel
	try
		tell application "Image Events"
			launch
			-- open the image file
			set this_image to open this_file
			-- perform action
			scale this_image to size 640
			-- save the changes
			save this_image with icon
			-- purge the open image data
			close this_image
		end tell
	on error error_message
		display dialog error_message
	end try
end repeat

title: Really a required keyword?!
this works nicely
contents:
(defun memcached-get (key &key ((:ip ip) *memcached-server-ip*) ((:port port) *memcached-server-port*))
  "Retrive value for key from memcached server.
   key => is the key by which data is stored in memcached
   ip  => is the ip of the memcached server
   port => is the port on which the memcached server runs"
  (with-open-stream (s (trivial-sockets:open-stream ip port))
   (format s "get ~a~%" key)
   (force-output s)
   (let ((first-line (read-line s nil nil)))
     (unless (search "END" first-line)
       (let* ((len (parse-integer (fourth (cl-ppcre:split "\\s+" first-line))))
	     (seq (make-string len)))
	 (read-sequence seq s)
	 (read-line s nil nil)
	 seq)))))

title: custom lookup
contents:
(defun xgp-casi2-lookup-key (key)
  (or (if overriding-terminal-local-map
	  (lookup-key overriding-terminal-local-map key)
	(if overriding-local-map
	    (lookup-key overriding-local-map key)
	  (or
	   (let ((map (get-text-property (point) 'keymap)))
	     (if map
		 (lookup-key map key)))
	   (let (val)
	     (find t emulation-mode-map-alists
		   :test 'equal
		   :key '(lambda (alist)
			   (if (setq val (xgp-casi2-lookup-key-from-alist key alist))
			       t)))
	     val)
	   (xgp-casi2-lookup-key-from-alist key minor-mode-overriding-map-alist)
	   (xgp-casi2-lookup-key-from-alist key minor-mode-map-alist)
	   (let ((map (get-text-property (point) 'local-map)))
	     (if map
		 (lookup-key map key)))
	   (lookup-key (current-local-map) key))))
      (lookup-key (current-global-map) key)))

(defun xgp-casi2-lookup-key-from-alist (key alist)
  (let (val)
    (find t alist :test 'equal :key '(lambda (map)
				       (setq map (cdr map))
				       (if (setq val (lookup-key map key))
					   t)))
    val))

title: find-optional-argument-values
contents:
(defun find-optional-argument-values (arglist provided-args &optional
                                      (split-arglist
                                       (split-lambda-list-on-keywords
                                        arglist)))
  "Return an association list mapping symbols of optional or
  keyword arguments from `arglist' to the specified values in
  `provided-args'. `Split-arglist' should be either a split
  arglist or nil, in which case it will be calculated from
  `arglist'."
  ;; First we check whether any optional arguments have even been
  ;; provided.
  (flet ((get-args (keyword)
           (rest (assoc keyword split-arglist))))
    (let* ((mandatory-args-count (length (get-args '&mandatory)))
           (optional-args-count (length (get-args '&optional)))
           (keyword-args-count (length (get-args '&key)))
           (provided-args-count (length provided-args))
           (nonmandatory-args-count (+ keyword-args-count
                                       optional-args-count)))
      (when (> provided-args-count
               mandatory-args-count)
        ;; We have optional arguments.
        (let (;; Find the part of the provided arguments that concern
              ;; optional arguments.
              (opt-args-values (subseq provided-args
                                       mandatory-args-count
                                       (min provided-args-count
                                            nonmandatory-args-count)))
              ;; Find the part of the provided arguments that concern
              ;; keyword arguments.
              (keyword-args-values (subseq provided-args
                                           (+ mandatory-args-count
                                              optional-args-count))))
          (append (mapcar #'cons
                          (get-args '&optional)
                          opt-args-values)

                  (loop ;; Loop over the provided keyword symbols and
                     ;; values in the argument list. Note that
                     ;; little checking is done to ensure that the
                     ;; given symbols are valid - this is not a
                     ;; compiler, so extra mappings do not
                     ;; matter.
                     for (keyword value) on keyword-args-values by #'cddr
                     if (keywordp keyword)
                     collect (cons (intern (symbol-name keyword))
                                   value))))))))
